questions.text: The following appearance on ERCP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The given appearance of the fish-eye lesion of the ampulla of Vater on ERCP is characteristic of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). 

Mucin can be seen extruding from the ampulla of Vater, a so-called fish-eye lesion that is virtually diagnostic of IPMN.

questions.text: The CT scan image of a 50-year-old female with backache is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the classical polka dot sign(on axial section) and the Corduroy sign /jailhouse appearance(on vertical section). These are seen in vertebral hemangioma.

These signs are the result of the replacement of normal cancellous bone by thickened vertical trabeculae.

The corduroy sign is shown in the following image.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is unlikely to be associated with the lesion seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is least likely to be associated with the posterior urethral valve.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lie in front of L3 vertebra due to arrest of ascent.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Wilms tumor
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney
  • Turner’s syndrome

questions.text: Penicillin is most likely to kill the bacteria in which phase of the bacterial growth curve shown below?
questions.solution:
The log (logarithmic) phase, also known as the exponential phase is when rapid cell division occurs. β -Lactam drugs, such as penicillin, act during this phase because the drugs are effective when cells are making peptidoglycan (i.e., when they are dividing).

The first is the lag phase, during which vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide. This can last for a few minutes up to many hours.
The stationary phase occurs when nutrient depletion or toxic products cause growth to slow until the number of new cells produced balances the number of cells that die, resulting in a steady-state.
The final phase is the death phase, which is marked by a decline in the number of viable bacteria.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the test shown in the image.

choices.text: < 5 mm of moisture - severe Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Fluorescein dye test is an alternative

questions.solution:
The image shows a Schirmer’s test being performed. It is measured after 5 minutes, not 10 minutes.

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A patient with lepromatous leprosy presents with eye pain. The image of his eye is given below. Identify the finding marked by the arrow:
questions.solution:
The finding marked by the arrow in the image of the eye of a patient with lepromatous leprosy is the iris pearl, which is a pathognomonic finding of leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae. Ocular features in leprosy occur due to bacterial invasion. They include the following:

  • Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
  • Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
  • Miosis
  • Iris atrophy
  • Iris pearls 
  • Retinal pearls
  • Other features are scleritis, episcleritis, cataracts, diminished corneal sensation, etc. 

Other options:

Option A: Brushfield spots refer to small white speckles on the peripheral iris that are arranged in a concentric ring. They are seen in Down’s syndrome and may sometimes be a normal finding in blue eyes. The image below shows Brushfield spots.

Option C: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Option D: Busacca nodules are present on the iris stroma. They are seen in granulomatous uveitis.

The image below shows Koeppe nodules. These are present at the pupillary border and are seen in anterior uveitis.

questions.text: During a community outreach program in a rural area, you come across a girl with a conjunctival lesion as shown in the image. According to the WHO grading, which grade does this child falls under?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Bitot’s spot, which is seen in the X1B stage of vitamin A deficiency.

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: The imaginary plane passing through the bony prominences marked in red in the image below lies at the level of________.
questions.solution:
The structures marked in red are the tubercles of the iliac crest. An imaginary line passing through them forms the trans-tubercular plane which lies at the upper border of L5. 

The abdomen is divided into 9 regions based on the following:

  • Two transverse planes:
    • Subcostal plane which is indicated by a line that joins the lowest point of the costal margin on each side. It corresponds to the level of 10th costal cartilage and lower border of second lumbar vertebra(L2) or upper border of third lumbar vertebra (L3) 
    • Trans-tubercular plane is indicated by a line that joins the tubercles of the iliac crests. It corresponds to the level of fifth lumbar vertebra (L5).
  • Two vertical planes on both sides:
    • Right and left lateral planes passing from mid-clavicular point to the mid-inguinal point.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: On suddenly dropping an infant’s head in relation to her trunk, you notice the response seen in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding different components of this response?

choices.text: Hand opening is present by 28 weeks
Upper limb extension and abduction is present by 32 weeks
Anterior flexion with audible cry appears by 40 weeks

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates Moro’s Reflex. In Moro's reflex, anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks.

 The different components of Moro's reflex appear as following:

  • Hand opening appears at 28 weeks.
  • Upper Limb extension and abduction appear at 32 weeks.
  • Anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks

Moro’s reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age.

An asymmetrical Moro's reflex is indicative of root plexus injury.

Moro’s is considered to be the only unlearned fear in human newborns.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

Onset

Duration

32 weeks of gestation
2-3 months postnatal
Rooting
32 weeks of gestation
36 weeks of gestation
Less prominent after 1 month postnatal
Moro
28-32 weeks of gestation
37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal
Tonic neck
35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal
3-4 months postnatal
Parachute
7-8 months postnatal
10-11 months postnatal
Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells, along with DOG1.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used. 

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

Most common Structure/Conditions
Congenital intestinal atresia Imperforate anus
True diverticulum Meckel's diverticulum
Site of ischemia Colon
Site of fistulization Esophagus
Site of GI polyp Colorectum
Malignancy of GI tract Adenocarcinoma colon
Cause of esophagitis Acid reflux
Benign tumor of the esophagus Leiomyoma
Esophageal cancer in India and worldwide Squamous cell carcinoma
Esophageal cancer in Western countries Adenocarcinoma
Type of chronic gastritis Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
Malignancy of the stomach Adenocarcinoma
Site of extranodal lymphoma Stomach
Mesenchymal tumor of the stomach Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
Tumor of small intestine/appendix Carcinoid

 

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: Fracture through the line shown in the image is called as?
questions.solution:
The line shown in the given image corresponds closely to the location of a hinge fracture of the base of the skull, also called a motorcyclist's fracture.

It is a basal linear fracture that passes across the floor of the middle cranial fossa, often following the petrous temporal or greater wing of the sphenoid bone into the pituitary fossa. This frequently continues symmetrically across the other middle fossa separating the base of the skull into two halves, usually being caused by a heavy blow on the side of the head and is associated with injuries to the brainstem (pontomedullary tears).

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: What is the type of joint shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The type of joint shown is amphiarthroses.

They are joints at which some movements are possible. They have cartilage in between the bony surfaces which act as shock absorbers. The bony cartilage complex is supported externally by many fibrous ligaments.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of women with fishy odor vaginal discharge is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV). The microscopic finding is vaginal epithelial cells with bacteria attached to their surface called clue cells, creating a poorly defined cellular border. They are the most reliable indicators of BV. 

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by a decrease in lactobacilli and an overgrowth of anaerobic bacterial species, including gardnerella, prevotella,mobiluncus, and bacteroides. Multiple or new sexual partners, having female partners, and engaging in oral sex are associated with a higher risk of BV. They may experience a foul-smelling (fishy odor) thin vaginal discharge. 

The clinical diagnosis of BV is based on the presence of three out of four Amsel criteria: elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), thin noninflammatory discharge, >20% clue cells, and a fishy odor (positive whiff test) after adding 10% potassium hydroxide to a vaginal sample. creating a poorly defined cellular border. 

BV is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes such as preterm birth, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and postpartum endometritis. It also increases susceptibility to sexually transmitted infections, including HIV.

The recommended treatment options in nonpregnant women include oral metronidazole, metronidazole gel, or clindamycin cream. Alternative options include oral secnidazole, tinidazole, or clindamycin. Partner treatment is not needed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with a soap bubble appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone.

GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.

GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue.

Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma.

Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally.

Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT.

 Note: The E mnemonic for GCT:

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: A 24 year old primi with a history of 3 months of amenorrhoea undergoes USG.  The USG done is suggestive of

choices.text: Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
The above USG is suggestive of Hydatidiform mole.

The USG shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance which is seen in hydatidiform mole.

It is of 2 types

  • Complete mole - grossly appear as a mass of clear vesicles.
  • Partial mole - has less hydatidiform changes and contains some fetal tissue.


Classical clinical features of a complete mole are-

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance.

questions.text: True statement regarding the targets/objectives of the campaign whose logo is shown below:

choices.text: Prevention of gender-biased sex selective elimination

questions.solution:
Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao - “Save the daughter, educate the daughter” is a campaign of the Government of India that aims to generate awareness and improve the efficiency of welfare services intended for girls.

The objectives of BBBP are:

  • To prevent gender-biased sex-selective elimination
  • To ensure survival and protection of the girl child
  • To ensure education and participation of the girl child

The targets of this campaign are:

  1. Improve the Sex Ratio at Birth (SRB) in selected gender critical districts by 2 points in a year.
  2. Reduce Gender differentials in Under Five Child Mortality Rate from 7 points in 2014 to 1.5 points per year
  3. At least a 1.5 % increase per year of Institutional Deliveries.
  4. At least a 1% increase per year of 1st Trimester ANC Registration.
  5. Increase enrolment of girls in secondary education to 82% by 2018-19.
  6. Provide functional toilets for girls in every school in selected districts.
  7. Improve the Nutrition status of girls - by reducing the number of underweight and anemic girls under 5 years of age.
  8. Ensure universalization of ICDS, girls’ attendance and equal care monitored, using joint ICDS NHM Mother-Child Protection Cards.
  9. Promote a protective environment for Girl Children through the implementation of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act 2012.
  10. Train Elected Representatives/ Grassroot functionaries as Community Champions to mobilize communities to improve CSR and promote Girl’s education.

questions.text: The patient presents with sudden onset of fever and painful burning lesions on his right knee. Which of the following is not indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A systemic response(fever), along with prodromal symptoms like pain and presence of grouped herpetiform vesicles developing on the erythematous base is classical of Herpes zoster infection. In this case fluconazole is not indicated.

Tricyclic antidepressants are given for the management of pain.

Glucocorticoids are given for reduction of inflammation. However, it should not be used without concomitant antiviral therapy.

questions.text: What does the given barium swallow film show?
questions.solution:
The given barium swallow film shows an outpouching from the posterior wall of the pharynx suggestive of a Zenker's diverticulum (pharyngeal pouch). 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

 

Diverticula Weak space Site
Zenker diverticulum Killian triangle/ Killian dehiscence

Above the upper esophageal sphincter

Between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle
Laimer's diverticulum Laimer’s triangle/ Laimer–Hackermann’s area

Posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus
Killian– Jamieson Diverticulum Killian–Jamieson area
 
Laterally between the oblique and transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus
at its attachment to the cricoid cartilage

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

Granular IgA in some cases

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: Identify the subtype of Hodgkin’s lymphoma based on the cell marked as A in the image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows popcorn cell which is characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

Popcorn cell is lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of RS cells that has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn.

L&H variants usually are found within large nodules containing mainly small B cells along with variable numbers of macrophages. The immunophenotype is CD20+ve, CD15−ve and C30−ve 

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: Considering the image given, the most common site of airway collapse in obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) is ________
questions.solution:
The soft palate (B in the image) is the most common site for airway collapse in OSAHS. Other sites include the base of tongue (A), lateral pharyngeal wall (C) and/or epiglottis (D).

Note:

OSAHS may be particularly severe in the supine position, due to gravitational forces, and during REM sleep as the neuromuscular output to muscles is particularly low.

questions.text: During ventral hernia repair the surgeon places a polypropylene mesh in the location marked by point D in the given image. What type of mesh position does this signify?
questions.solution:
The type of mesh repair marked as 'D' shows preperitoneal mesh repair.

Inlay repairs involve the mesh being sutured to the fascial edge without overlap. It is associated with a high recurrence rate.

Onlay or overlay involves the placement of mesh over anterior fascia. The mesh is placed outside abdominal cavity

Underlay (Sublay) involves the placement of mesh placed below fascial components. Placement of mesh can be either retrorectus, preperitoneal or intraperitoneal

questions.text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.

It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 

Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.

Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: The following anatomical classification of pelvis was given by ______and is based on _________
questions.solution:
This classification is given by Caldwell and Moloy.
This classification is based on shape of the pelvis.
The greatest transverse diameter of the inlet and its division into anterior and posterior segments are used to classify pelvis as

  • Gynaecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about fibromuscular dysplasia?

choices.text: String of beads appearance on angiography
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows:

  1. Renal arteries
  2. Carotid arteries
  3. Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries

On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

questions.text: The given image depicts Brown-Sequard syndrome. The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion. Which of the following is inappropriately matched?
questions.solution:
The part marked 3 is incorrectly matched. Discriminative touch (also known as fine touch) is lost on the ipsilateral side of the lesion in Brown Sequard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features.

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: The probable diagnosis based on the below clinical image of the breast is?
questions.solution:
The image shows a thrombosed subcutaneous cord attached to the skin of the breast which is the pathognomic feature of Mondor's Disease.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. It may also occur in the arm or penis. On raising the arm, the skin over the chest gets stretched and a narrow, shallow groove alongside the cord is seen. It is treated by restricting arm movements and usually subsides within a few months without recurrence, complications, or deformity.

The differential diagnosis to be considered is lymphatic permeation from an occult carcinoma of the breast.

Other options:

Option A: Paget’s disease is a type of ductal carcinoma in situ arising from the nipple and commonly presents as nipple erosion.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Option D: Tietze’s syndrome refers to the benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

questions.text: The given image shows a newborn brought to the OPD by his mother who has noticed the whitish lesions. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows Milia.

Milia are:

  • Also known as “milk spots”
  • Pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts.
  • Located over the face usually.
  • Resolve spontaneously without scarring.
  • Require no treatment.

Milia is distinct from Miliaria.

Miliaria is a disease of the eccrine sweat gland.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the cartilage shown?

choices.text: Corniculate cartilage is an example of this cartilage type

questions.solution:
The cartilage shown in the image above is hyaline cartilage. Corniculate cartilage is an elastic cartilage. 

Hyaline cartilage can be identified by homogenous matrix and chondrocytes arranged as cell nests in lacunae.

Among the cartilages of the larynx, thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid are hyaline cartilages. Whereas, epiglottis, corniculate, and cuneiform are elastic cartilages.

The following image shows hyaline cartilage:

The following image shows fibrocartilage:

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage

Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair

Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

questions.text: The dose-response curves of four different drugs are shown here. Which of the following drugs is the most potent?
questions.solution:
Drug 2 is the most potent among the other given drugs.

The potency and efficacy of a drug are represented by the dose-response curve.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. The more the curve is towards the left, the more the potency.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Drug 4 is most efficacious.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva, and stridor is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and thumb sign on the x-ray is acute epiglottitis.

Causative organisms are Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical features include high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, drooling, and progressing respiratory obstruction. Stridor appears late and indicates near-complete respiratory obstruction. Child sits in tripod position to relieve the obstruction.

Laryngoscopy shows large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis. X-ray of lateral view of neck shows thumb sign. Management is to give antibiotics and emergency endotracheal intubation is done as required.

Other options:

Option-A: Retropharyngeal abscess is often polymicrobial caused by streptococcus, staphylococcus, and anaerobes. Clinical features include fever, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice, and trismus. Management is by giving intravenous antibiotics with or without surgical drainage.

Option-B: Laryngomalacia is a congenital anomaly presenting with inspiratory stridor which is low-pitched and exacerbated by crying or feeding. Symptoms usually appear within the first two weeks of life. Most symptoms resolve spontaneously as the child and airway grow.

Option C: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection. Clinical features include low-grade fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. Steeple sign is seen on the x-ray due to subglottic narrowing. If the child is hypoxic, immediate airway management is done.

Steeple sign in croup appears as in the image below:

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Modified Prague’s maneuver is shown in the image. It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Other options:

Lovset’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

These lesions appear as ovoid or spherical, often laminated, PAS-positive nodules within the mesangial core of the glomerular lobules.

These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman capsules (“capsular drops”).

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

1. Glomerular lesions:

  1. Capillary basement membrane thickening
  2. Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
  3. Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease

2. Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis

3. Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: The condition seen in image starts to occur at intake levels of ________ of the offending agent.
questions.solution:
The image shows mottling of teeth seen in Fluorosis. It starts to occur at intake levels of 1.5 mg/L of fluoride. 

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10 mg/L

questions.text: A person complains of severe pain after he fell backwards on his elbow. His X-ray is shown below. What is the preferred treatment in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of the olecranon. Tension band wiring is one of the management methods in this case. 

The Mayo classification divides olecranon fractures into three groups based on fracture displacement and elbow stability. Each group is further subdivided into comminuted or noncomminuted fractures. 

  • Type I - Undisplaced fractures
  • Type II - Displaced but stable fractures
  • Type III - Unstable fractures

Treatment includes:

  • Type I fractures - non-operative management
  • Type II and III fractures - surgery
  • Simple fractures without comminution or instability - tension band wiring, plate fixation, or an intramedullary rod
  • Comminuted fractures and fractures with elbow instability - plate fixation 
  • Osteoporotic patients with significant comminution - excision of the olecranon and triceps advancement

Related Pearl: Tension Band Wiring

A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing.

It is used in:

  • Fracture patella
  • Fracture olecranon 
  • Fracture lateral malleolus
  • Fracture greater trochanter

The below image shows tension band wiring for a fracture olecranon

questions.text: The clinical finding in the given image is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis. ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. 

Option C: Angular stomatitis is the soreness at the angles of the mouth extending outwards in the folds of the facial skin.

Option D: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is caused by coxsackievirus. It is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

 Anti centromere

questions.text: A study on the prevalence of diabetes was conducted and the sampling method shown below was used. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.solution:
In this study, the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups and from these, random samples are drawn. This sampling method is called stratified random sampling.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: The movement disorder shown below is most likely to result from a lesion in
questions.solution:
The movement disorder depicted in the above image is hemiballismus, most commonly caused by a partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

Ballism is a severe choreiform movement disorder characterized by wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements, primarily affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballismus). It can also involve a single limb (monoballism) or, in rare cases, both upper or lower limbs (paraballism). The movements can be intense, leading to exhaustion, dehydration, injury, or even death in extreme cases.

The most common cause is a partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus (STN) due to infarction or hemorrhage. The subthalamic nucleus usually excites the globus pallidus internus, which inhibits the thalamus. Damage to this nucleus reduces the inhibition of the thalamus, resulting in excessive movement. However, dopamine-blocking drugs are often effective, and the condition is usually self-limiting, resolving within weeks to months. In severe cases, pallidotomy or deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the globus pallidus internus (GPi) can help control symptoms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with complaints of passing profuse loose stools which looked like rice water for the past 3 days. There's a history of similar symptoms in the family. Stool samples were sent to the lab for analysis and the test given in the image is performed. Identify this test.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of passing profuse rice-water stools with similar complaints in the family suggests a probable diagnosis of cholera. The test shown in the above image is the string test and it is performed to identify Vibrio cholerae.

To perform the string test, a loopful of the bacterial culture is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The bacterial cells of Vibrio cholerae are lysed by sodium deoxycholate, causing the suspension to lose its turbidity and become mucoid. A string is formed when the loop is drawn away from the suspension.

Note: The duodenal string test refers to the Entero test performed for the diagnosis of giardiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a wrong inference from the following product?

choices.text: The given product protects against skin cancer
SPF stands for specific protection factor
The given product protects against  sunburn
PABA is one of its ingredients

questions.solution:
SPF stands for Sun Protection Factor. The given product is a sunscreen and SPF is a measure of absorbing the erythrogenic ultraviolet rays by the sunscreen.

Sunscreens with SPF values of 15 or higher helps prevent not only sunburn but also extend their protection against skin cancer and early skin ageing. Those between 2 to 14 can help prevent only sunburns. Most of the sunscreens offers protection against UVB rays with a wavelength range of 280 to 320 nm as this range is the most common cause of erythema and sunburn.

Ingredients of sunscreen:

  • PABA
  • Benzophenones
  • Dibenzoylmethane

questions.text: Which of the following dermatological conditions is the likely cause of the characteristic nail finding shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate, which is seen in lichen planus. Thinning of the nail plate is the most frequent nail change seen in lichen planus.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

Various factors can precipitate the disease:

  • Viruses like hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), and varicella zoster virus
  • HLA-A3, HLA-5 association
  • Environmental factors like
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa is a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: While performing the following pediatric emergency procedure being performed on the model of an infant, which of the following indicates a wrong technique?

choices.text: Compression : Breath ratio should ideally be 30:2
Fingers should be lifted off the chest to allow effective recoil between compressions
Efficiency of chest compression should be assessed with brachial pulse periodically
Alternatively, the two thumb technique is equally effective

questions.solution:
The image shows infant CPR. Fingers should not be lifted off the chest between compressions.

The thumbs or the tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute.i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

In infants, the brachial pulse should be assessed. (For children aged one to adolescence, the pulse should be checked at the carotid artery)

The two-finger technique and two thumb technique are considered to be equally effective.

questions.text: Fracture shown in the radiograph is:
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows Aviator’s fracture. 

An aviator fracture is a coronal-plane fracture of the neck of the talus resulting from forced dorsiflexion of ankle. 

It is the second most common talar fracture, after talar dome fractures.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.
