questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 15-day old baby to you with complaints of decreased activity and vomiting. On examination, the baby is hypotensive, has depressed fontanelles and reduced skin turgor. The image of the external genitalia of the baby is shown below. Which electrolyte abnormality can you expect to see in this baby?
questions.solution:
The image shows ambiguous genitalia. This along with signs of dehydration and hypotension suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) can be seen in this condition. 

These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. On the second day, he becomes drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of management is decompressive surgery.

Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days. 

Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum. 

Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration ≤ 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving ≥ one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours ≥ 80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema.

World Stroke Day is on October 29 every year. On this day, people everywhere share important information about recognizing the signs of a stroke, how to stay healthy, and ways to prevent strokes. The theme this year, as designated by WSO, is ‘Together we are #Greater Than Stroke.’ In India, the average stroke incidence rate is 145 per 1,00,000 population.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen in the given image-
questions.solution:
The type of hymen in the image is cribriform.

Cribriform hymen has multiple sievelike small openings.

Some of the variants of hymen are:

  • Imperforate - without any opening
  • Microperforate - tiny opening
  • Annular - oval central opening
  • Septate - two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue
  • Naviculate - boatlike opening

questions.text: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta or hypernasality of speech will be seen in this condition of cleft palate.

It is seen when certain words which have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. The defect is the failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities.

Common causes are:

  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Congenitally short soft palate
  • Submucous palate
  • Large nasopharynx
  • Cleft of soft palate
  • Paralysis of soft palate
  • Post adenoidectomy
  • Oronasal fistula
  • Familial speech pattern
  • Habitual speech pattern.

NOTE:

  • Clausa = Close; closed nose and nasopharynx
  • Aperta = Open/aperture; abnormally open nose and nasopharynx

questions.text: The image shows a male child with an anterior abdominal wall that is flabby and thin.   The bowel contours appear obvious on inspection and on examination the scrotum is empty. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Prune Belly Syndrome.

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: The image depicts the quantitative test for fetomaternal hemorrhage. What inference can be derived from this test?

choices.text: Fetal RBCs are washed out and maternal RBCs are red
Maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are washed out and few immature RBCs are alone red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are red and few immature RBCs are washed out

questions.solution:
The test shown is the Kleihauer-Betke test. The test shows that the maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red. This is because the fetal RBCs are resistant to acid digestion.

Principle of this test is that the fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. These fetal cells are counted per 50 low-power fields. If there are 80 fetal erythrocytes in 50 low-power fields in maternal peripheral blood films, it represents a transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4 mL of fetal blood. 10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: The image given below shows an eyeball with a refractive error. All the following fundal changes can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. Hence, the refractive error is myopia. All the fundal changes mentioned above can be seen in myopia, except cattle track appearance.

Cattle truck appearance is seen in branch retinal artery occlusion (not myopia).

Pathological/degenerative myopia is characterized by progressive anteroposterior elongation of the scleral envelope associated with secondary ocular changes due to mechanical stretching of the involved tissues.

Clinically patients present with defective vision, floating black opacities (muscae volitantes), and difficulty with night vision. Examination of the fundus reveals the following changes:

  • Optic disc:
    • Temporal myopic crescent
  • Retina and choroid:
    • Lacquer cracks are fine irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole, due to ruptures in the Bruch membrane.
    • Subretinal coin hemorrhages develop from lacquer cracks.
    • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion at the macula which develops after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed.
    • A pale tessellated (tigroid) appearance of the fundus is seen due to diffuse attenuation of the RPE with large choroidal vessels.
    • Lattice degeneration
  • Vitreous: Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) appears as Weiss' reflex.
  • Posterior staphyloma.

The image given below shows fundal changes seen in pathological myopia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

Related Pearl: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

  • Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.
  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics bind to the subunit of the ribosome marked by the black arrow and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline binds to the 30S subunit of the ribosome and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.

Protein synthesis is important for maintaining certain vital functions in bacteria. Hence by interrupting the protein synthesis, they act as bacteriostatic agents.

Antibacterial which binds to the 30s subunit of 70s ribosome.

  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides

Antibacterials that bind to 50s subunit of 70s ribosome.

  • Macrolides
  • Clindamycin
  • Streptogramins
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Linezolid

questions.text: Which among the following finding is predominantly seen in the layer of retina highlighted below?
questions.solution:
The highlighted layer given in the image is the outer plexiform layer (identified as it lies between two nuclear layers). Hard exudates mostly occur in this layer.

Hard Exudates - extravasation of fluid rich in fibrin and protein around the area of microaneurysms. They mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer. They appear as well defined bright yellow deposits.

Soft Exudates  -  also known as ‘cotton wool spots’ occur due to the accumulation of cellular debris that occurs as a result of ischemia. They are seen in the nerve fiber layer. They appear as ill-defined, cloud-like soft aggregates with feathery margins.

Flame haemorrhages -  It is due to the rupture of blood vessels in the nerve fiber layer. They assume flame shape because of the collection of blood in between the parallel running nerve fibers.

Drusen - are extracellular deposits located in the interface between retinal pigmentary epithelium and Bruch membrane.

The following image shows different layers of retina.

 

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  1. Internal limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of fever and malaise. He also complains of an itchy rash which first appeared on the trunk as shown below. When is this disease the most contagious?

choices.text: 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash
7 days before to 7 days after the onset of rash
4 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash

questions.solution:
The rash (different stages at one time) in the image and the clinical history are suggestive of chickenpox. The period of communicability for chickenpox is 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash.

Related Pearl: Period of communicability of important diseases

 

Disease Period of communicability
Chicken pox  1-2 days before to 4-5 days after appearance of rash
Hepatitis B One month before the appearance of Jaundice till the disappearance of HbsAg
Measles 4 days before to 5 days after appearance of rash
Rubella 7 days before to 7 days after the rash
Mumps 4-6 days before to 7 days after symptoms onset

Diphtheria Up to 4 weeks after disease onset

Influenza 1 to 2 days before and 1 to 2 days after onset of symptoms
Tetanus Not communicable

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency most commonly causes the disease shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a child with albinism and is due to a deficiency of copper-containing enzyme tyrosinase causing a defect in melanin production. The affected child has milky white hair and milky white skin.

In untreated phenylketonuria, the baby looks normal at birth, with a skin and hair color lighter than other members of the family. Later, the child has blonde hair, skin with a light complexion, and blue irides. Manifestations are not so severe as in OCA. The image shows an infant with white hair, so albinism is the best choice.

Note - Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Tyrosine is first hydroxylated to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase. This enzyme is abundant in the central nervous system, the sympathetic ganglia, and the adrenal medulla.

questions.text: Barium swallow of a patient presenting with dysphagia is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a patient presenting with dysphagia and a corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a hypermotility disorder caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen primarily affecting the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body, with normal deglutitive lower esophageal relaxation (LES) relaxation. These contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude, but normal peristalsis is preserved between the episodes. This condition is seen most often in females.

Patients typically present with dysphagia for both solids and liquids, retrosternal non-cardiac chest pain, and symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation and the sensation of food being stuck in the throat.

Although DES may present as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus on barium swallow, this finding is uncommon. Manometry remains the gold-standard for diagnosis.
 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 μm) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

 

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cryptosporidium species.

In immunocompromised patients, the infection causes severe diarrhea similar to cholera and require hospitalization.

The diagnosis is made with stool microscopy. The cyst wall and sporoblasts are dyed red with the Ziehl–Neelsen (warm) or Kinyoun (cold) staining methods. Both methods have good specificity and therefore are useful as confirmatory tests.

The treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Identify the plot.
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

Related Pearl: Diseases and Usual Joints affected

Disease Joint
Gout MTP of great toe
Pseudogout Knee
Rheumatoid arthritis Metacarpophalangeal joint
Ankylosing spondylitis Sacro-iliac joint
Septic arthritis Knee
Syphilitic arthritis Knee
Gonococcal arthritis Knee
Diabetic Charcot joint Foot joint(midtarsal)
Senile osteoporosis Vertebra
Paget's disease
 Pelvis > Femur >Skull >Tibia
Osteochondritis dissecans Knee >Elbow
(Most common cause of loose bodies in young)
Actinomycosis Mandible
Hemophilic arthritis Knee(Children-Ankle)
Acute osteomyelitis Lower end of femur(Metaphysis)
Brodie's abscess Upper end of tibia

questions.solution:
The given image is the cross-section of secondary chorionic villi, as it contains the mesodermal core surrounded by cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts.

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Surgeon's knot. It is a very stable knot.

questions.text: The toxin not associated with the fungus shown in the image is
questions.solution:
The image shows mushroom and aflatoxin is not produced by it. Aflatoxin is produced by Aspergillus fungi in improperly stored food grains.

The toxins that are commonly associated with mushrooms are

  • Amatoxin
  • Gyromitrin
  • Muscarine

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in association with the condition shown in the image below ?
questions.solution:
The image shows minimal change disease in which effacement of foot process can be seen. Hepatitis B is not seen in association with minimal change disease.

Secondary causes of minimal change disease:

  • Infections : HIV
  • Drugs : Rifampicin, Interferons, NSAIDS
  • Malignancy : Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Allergy

Minimal change disease is also called as NIL's lesion because there is no abnormality seen in light microcopy of kidney biopsy , but it shows effacement of foot process on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Among the given options the given structure is of the capillary.

The wall of the capillary is formed mainly by endothelial cells that are lined on the outside by a basal lamina made of glycoprotein. There is no adventitia that differentiates it from a venule.

The image below shows the microvessels - arteriole, venule, and capillary.

The capillaries can be classified into two types:

  1. Continuous capillaries - The edges of endothelial cells fuse completely with those of adjoining cells to form a continuous wall. The exchange of material between the blood and tissue occurs through the cytoplasm of the endothelial cells or through the intercellular material adjoining the cells.
  2. Fenestrated capillaries - The walls of these capillaries have apertures in their endothelial lining which are closed by a thin diaphragm. The fenestration may also be present as pores, which passes through the entire thickness of the cell. The exchange of material occurs by diffusion through these fenestrae. They are mainly seen in renal glomeruli, intestinal villi, endocrine glands, and pancreas.

Sinusoids differ from the capillaries in that the wall sinusoid has only endothelium, which is supported by a thin layer of connective tissue. The endothelium has larger deficiencies in the form of fenestrations or long slits.

questions.text:
The flow-volume loop given below in purple most likely denotes?
(Considering Blue flow volume loop denotes the normal)
questions.solution: The given flow volume loop is indicative of fixed upper airway obstruction like tracheal stenosis.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Above image shows Lisch nodules which is the most common ocular lesion in Neurofibromatosis type-1. Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas, usually clear yellow to brown, that appear as well-defined, dome-shaped elevations projecting from the surface of the iris.

Neurofibromatosis  

  • NF-1 is a autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutation in gene located on chromosome 17. 
  • Hallmark of NF-1 is cafe-au-lait spots and multiple neurofibromas. The typical order of appearance of clinical manifestations is café-au-lait macules, axillary and/or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas), and neurofibromas.
  • Ash-leaf macules, shagreen patches are cutaneous manifestations seen in Tuberous sclerosis. It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by cutaneous manifestations, multiple benign tumors in CNS, heart, kidney, eyes. 
  • Brushfield spots are white or yellow colored spots seen on anterior surface of the irides. They are present in 85% of blue or hazel eyed patients with trisomy 21(Down syndrome).

Brushfield spots as shown in the images below:

questions.text: A patient with infective endocarditis is started on an intravenous antibiotic and has developed the following reaction within a few minutes of starting it. What is the most likely antibiotic which can cause this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given image shows red man syndrome and the drug causing it is vancomycin.

Red man syndrome is a common adverse effect of the rapid administration of vancomycin. The redness is due to the release of histamine in the body. This should always be anticipated while giving vancomycin infusion and can be prevented by prior administration of antihistamines and prolonging the infusion period to 1 to 2 hours.

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Blue man syndrome - Amiodarone
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Glutamic acid in 6th position of beta chain is replaced by histidine
Glutamic acid in 6th position of alpha chain is replaced by proline
Glutamic acid in 6th position of beta chain is replaced by valine
Glutamic acid in 6th position of alpha chain is replaced by tryptophan

questions.solution: The given image shows sickled red blood cells. The primary defect in HbS is the amino acid glutamic acid in the 6th position of the beta chain of hemoglobin is replaced by valine.

questions.text: A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress soon after birth. On examination, the child has frothing of saliva and the resident suspects tracheoesophageal fistula. What is the most common type of fistula likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution:
Type C is the commonest variety of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). 

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. The proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. 

Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggest a diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: Given below is an image of a section of the small intestine. Identify the structure marked X
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the above given image of a section of ileum is the MALT (Mucosal associated lymphoid tissue), also known as gut-associated lymphoid tissue. These are seen as aggregated lymphatic follicle or Peyer's patch present in the submucosa of the ileum. 

The mucosal associated lymphoid tissues are present in other regions as follows:

  • Tonsils - near the junction of the oral cavity with the pharynx, as collections of lymphoid tissue. The largest of these are the right and left palatine tonsils, present on either side of the oropharyngeal isthmus.
  • Solitary lymphatic follicles - small collections of lymphoid tissue, similar in structure to the follicles of lymph nodes, present anywhere along the length of the gut.
  • Aggregated lymphatic follicles (Peyer’s patches) - larger aggregations of lymphoid tissue, each consisting of 10 to 200 follicles present in the small intestine.

The image below of an ileal section shows Peyer's patches within the submucosa.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child requires bronchodilator therapy. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following is false about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Systemic absorption of drugs is unaffected

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spacer device. It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects like dysphonia that occur with the use of a pMDI.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. The systemic absorption is unchanged by the use of a spacer.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.

The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

  • Pressurized metered-dose inhalers - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of a drug
  • Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children <7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 
  • Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -
    • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
    • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic depicted from the following epidemic curve.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time. It occurs within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient has been given an intradermal injection of 0.1ml PPD (5 tuberculin units) over the forearm.   After 72 hrs, the site is examined as shown in the image below. What is the interpretation of the result obtained?

choices.text: Tuberculin test negative, suggesting immunity from TB
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting an active infection
Tuberculin test negative, suggesting a recent or past infection
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting a recent or past infection

questions.solution:
The above image shows an induration of >10 mm after 72 hrs of intradermal PPD injection suggesting a positive tuberculin test(TST), indicating recent or past infection. 

In TST, 0.1 ml of PPD (purified protein derivative) containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally and induration is read after 48-72 hours. An induration of 10 mm or more is considered positive in patients from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Surrounding erythema is not considered. 

A positive tuberculin test indicates hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein, denoting either latent infection with tubercle bacilli, or BCG immunization, or recent or past infection with or without clinical disease. 

False positives may be seen in infections with related mycobacteria and false negatives in miliary tuberculosis, severely immunosuppressed states, etc. 

Related Pearl: Tuberculin reaction size & candidates for treatment of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

Risk Group Positive Tuberculin Reaction Size
HIV infected persons ≥5 mm
Recent contacts of a patient with TB ≥5 mm
Organ transplant recipients ≥5 mm
Persons with fibrotic lesions consistent with old TB on chest radiography ≥5 mm
Immunosuppressed persons ≥5 mm
Persons with high risk medical conditions (silicosis & end stage renal disease) ≥5 mm
Injection drug users ≥10 mm
Mycobacteriology lab personnel ≥10 mm
Children <5 years of age ≥10 mm
Recent immigrants from high prevalence countries

≥10 mm
Low-risk persons

           ≥15 mm

 

Tuberculin reactions are read at 48-72 hr as the transverse diameter of the induration, and the diameter of the erythema is NOT considered.

questions.text: Identify the crystal given below.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts characteristic coffin lid crystals of triple phosphate (ammonium magnesium phosphate) or struvite.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the hernia sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

Option A: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Petersen hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon, and the retroperitoneum, after any type of gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: Identify the illumination system in the image below.
questions.solution:
Illumination system/ light source of microscope is marked as 2 in the image. It is a steady light source used in place of a mirror.

1 is objective lens. There are usually 3 or 4 objective lenses on a microscope. They almost always consist of 4X, 10X, 40X and 100X powers.

3 is coarse focusing knob. It moves the body tubes with its lenses.

4 is condenser. The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light onto the specimen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

  • Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).
  • Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.
  • Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.
  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.
  • Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: A woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility, and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium. 

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

Proliferative phase

  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiralled.
  • The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium

Secretory phase 

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)
  • Corkscrew-shaped glands

The image below shows secretory endometrium

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

Subcutaneous mycoses

 Causative agent/s

Sporotrichosis
  • Sporothrix schenckii
Chromoblastomycosis
  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Fonsecaea compact
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa
  • Cladophialophora carrionii

Phaeohyphomycosis
  • Exophiala jeanselmei
  • Phialophora richardsiae
  • Bipolaris spicifera
  • Wangiella dermatitidis

Mycetoma
  • Pseudallescheria boydii (Anamorph Scedosporium apiospermum).
  • Madurella mycetomatis
  • Madurella grisea
  • E jeanselmei
  • Acremonium falciforme

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid. His last meal was one hour ago. What pattern of gastric mucosal injury would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The area marked in image 2 depicts the most likely pattern of gastric mucosal injury in this patient.

The pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take in a food-filled stomach is known as magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach. This is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place, in corrosive injury. 

In an empty stomach, the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus (image 3).

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is this finding characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows a confluent macular violaceous erythema called the V sign seen in patients of dermatomyositis.

It is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle and usually presents initially with a facial rash, especially around eyelids, which can be pruritic and sore. Myositis symptoms are usually weakness and fatigue especially while climbing stairs, raising arms, and standing from sitting due to proximal muscle weakness.

The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

The clinical signs seen in dermatomyositis are as follows:

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron papules - flat-topped lichenoid eruption on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joint
  • Shawl sign or V sign - fixed erythematous macular erythema
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare
  • Calcinosis cutis

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male comes with fever, maculopapular lesions over the face and red-eye. On examination, he has unilateral LMN facial palsy. The chest X-ray and computed tomography of the head are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows mediastinal widening and possible mediastinal lymph node enlargement. The CT shows a bilateral parotid enlargement. This along with red eyes (anterior uveitis) and LMN facial palsy suggests Heerfordt's syndrome denoting acute sarcoidosis.

One-third of patients with sarcoidosis may present with skin lesions like erythema nodosum, maculopapular rashes, hypo-hyper pigmented lesions.

Lupus pernio is a specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks, which is diagnostic of chronic sarcoidosis. Hence the lesion is not Lupus pernio.

Lofgren's syndrome is also a form of acute sarcoidosis presenting with erythema nodosum, arthritis and bilateral lymphadenopathy.

Mumps is not associated with facial palsy.

Tolosa Hunt syndrome consists retro orbital or unilateral peri orbital pain associated with ophthalmoparesis of the 3rd, 4th, 6th cranial nerves with pain relief after beginning corticosteroid.

questions.text: All of the following hormones act via the given pathway except ______
questions.solution:
Estrogen acts through nuclear receptors.

The rest of the hormones in the options act through GPCRs via the cAMP second messenger pathway, which is seen in the image. 

  • The image shows binding of the hormones with the receptor which allows the coupling of the recep­tor to a G protein, leading to activation of adenylate cyclase. 
  • Activated adenylate cyclase then catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cAMP (2nd messenger). 
  • cAMP then activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase A which phosphorylates certain proteins leading to a physiological response.

Hormones using cAMP as the second messenger:

  • CRH, ACTH, Catecholamines (β1 and β2 receptors)
  • Parathyroid Hormone (PTH), calcitonin
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH)
  • FSH, LH, hCG
  • TSH
  • ADH (V2 receptors)
  • Glucagon
  • Somatostatin
  • Secretin

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen.

An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ infarts is thromboembolism.

The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to casualty after falling from a balcony. Based on the CT scan finding provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity, consistent with an epidural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the inner surface of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater, typically following a history of trauma. The characteristic biconvex shape arises due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of periosteal dura to the cranial sutures. If bleeding is significant, it may lead to a mass effect with herniation. 

Additionally, a swirl sign may be present, representing acute blood extravasation into a hematoma (extradural/subdural), showing fresh, unclotted blood with lower attenuation than the clotted blood (which is of a higher attenuation), highlighting the need for surgical intervention.

The following CT image depicts a swirl sign:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a primary health center. On 5th May 2023, you took a look at these 4 vaccine vials. Vial 1 had an expiry date of 4th May 2023 and the rest of the vials had an expiry date of 14th October 2023. Which of the following vials could be used?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, only vial 2 can be used.

According to the vaccine vial monitor, vial 1 and vial 2 can be used, but vial 2 is the one that was really fit for use as it had not yet expired as on 5th May 2023. Whereas, vial 1 has crossed the date of expiry.

Vial 3 and vial 4 should be discarded even though the drug has not expired. This is because the color in the inner square has matched the outer circle in vial 3 and is darker than the outer circle in vial 4.

Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are chemical indicator labels which are used to monitor the heat stability of the vaccines and are useful throughout the vaccine supply chain. The VVMs are designed to ensure that heat-damaged vaccines are not given to the patients. They also indicate preferable order of usage of the vials, thereby minimising vaccine wastage. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

Related Pearl: Temperature Sensitivity of Vaccines

Heat sensitivity in order of decreasing sensitivity:

Rotavirus(liquid)< T,DT,dT< IPV < Hib(liquid)< HepB < Pentavalent <DTaP

Vaccines not damaged by freezing:

  • Yellow fever
  • BCG
  • Hib
  • Japanese encephalitis(live and inactivated)
  • Measles, mumps, rubella
  • OPV
  • Rabies
  • Rotavirus(Freeze-dried)

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false?

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Quincke-type lumbar puncture needle. Coagulopathy is a contraindication to perform lumbar puncture (LP).

Contraindications for LP include:

  • Patients receiving anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications and those with coagulation defects
  • Possible raised intracranial pressure
  • Suspected spinal epidural abscess
  • Infection at the site of puncture

Before performing an LP, it is important to assess the patient's bleeding risk by checking their platelet count, international normalized ratio (INR), and partial thromboplastin time (PTT). LP is considered contraindicated if the platelet count is less than 20,000/μL, and some institutions recommend a platelet count of greater than 40,000/μL before proceeding with the procedure.

Proper positioning of the patient is crucial for an LP. The patient should lie on their side away from the examiner, with their knees bent and pulled up toward the abdomen (lateral decubitus). The neck should be gently bent forward, and the shoulders and pelvis should be aligned vertically. LP is typically performed at or below the L3-L4 interspace, which can be identified by palpating the spinous processes and using a line drawn between the posterior superior iliac crests as a guide.

Alternatively, the LP can be done with the patient seated upright, leaning forward to flex the back. This position is suitable for obese patients.

After sterile preparation of the insertion site and the injection of a local anesthetic, the LP needle is inserted midline between two spinous processes, with the bevel parallel to the dural fibers facing upwards. The needle is advanced until the subarachnoid space (SAS) is reached indicated by a loss of resistance. Once the SAS is reached, the opening pressure is measured, and CSF is allowed to drip into collection tubes for analysis.

A traumatic tap may cause a bloody tap, which can be differentiated from subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) by examining the supernatant after centrifugation. Prior to needle removal, the stylet is reinserted to prevent nerve entrapment and the development of a dural CSF leak. There is no need for prolonged recumbency after the procedure to prevent post-LP headache.

Neuroimaging is recommended before performing an LP in patients who have an altered level of consciousness, focal neurological deficits, new-onset seizures, or papilledema. This is because these patients are at a higher risk of developing cerebellar or tentorial herniation, a rare but potentially fatal complication. Imaging studies should also include the spine in patients with symptoms suggestive of spinal cord compression, such as back pain, leg weakness, urinary retention, or incontinence. In cases where acute meningitis is suspected and neuroimaging is necessary before the LP, it is recommended to administer antibiotics, preferably after blood culture, before conducting the imaging study.

The image below shows Quincke (dura cutting) and Whitacre (dura splitting) LP needles:

questions.text: Which is not true regarding this initiative?

choices.text: Is aimed towards adolescent girls to provide them sanitary napkins
Targets to provide sex education to adolescent girls
Includes both both boys and girls of adolescent age group
Comes under Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram

questions.solution:
The image here shows “Saathiya”, a government initiative launched to provide a platform for communication to adolescent age-related health issues.

Peer Educators (Saathiya), meaning “a good friend”, are trained by the government with the help of Saathiya salah mobile application.

These Saathiyas act as a catalyst for generating demand for adolescent health services and imparting age-appropriate knowledge on key adolescent health issues to their peer groups.

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) identifies six strategic priorities for adolescents i.e. nutrition, sexual and reproductive health (SRH), non-communicable diseases (NCDs), substance misuse, injuries and violence (including gender-based violence) and mental health.

“Suvidha” is the program aimed for the provision of sanitary napkins.

Sanitary napkins were made available for Rs.1 per pad at over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras across India.

The program aimed to ensure napkins were made available by May 28, 2018, celebrated as World Menstrual Hygiene Day.

questions.text: As evident from the relative sizes, the substances shown in the image are:

choices.text: A - LDL, B - VLDL, C - HDL
A - VLDL, B - HDL, C - LDL
A - HDL, B - VLDL, C - LDL
A - VLDL, B - LDL, C - HDL

questions.solution:
The image shows A - VLDL, B - LDL, C - HDL respectively.

The correct order of relative sizes is VLDL>LDL>HDL.

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25-year-old man who came to a primary health centre 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy. Which kit will be used for the management of this particular sexually transmitted disease?
questions.solution:
The appearance of painful genital ulcers, along with unilateral suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse best fits the symptom cluster of a non - herpetic genital ulcer. The treatment of which is kit 3 / white kit in case of no penicillin allergy.  

The above-shown clinical image and the findings are consistent with a diagnosis of chancroid.

Soft Chancre/Chancroid:

  • The causative organism is  Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The incubation period is 3 to 10 days.
  • It presents with multiple painful ulcers on genitals.
  • It may be accompanied by unilateral painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units + tab. Azithromycin 1 gm single dose

Note: In the syndromic approach to sexually transmitted infections, kit assignment based on the identification of a cluster of symptoms rather than making an actual diagnosis is given emphasis.

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

questions.text: What type of antagonism is shown by drugs A and B in the following dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
The parallel rightward shift of the agonist dose-response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism.

Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

In non-competitive antagonism, there will be flattening of the agonist DRC.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the Trochlear nerve. It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem.

  • Only cranial nerve with Dorsal exit
  • emerges from the midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course
  • Only nerve with internal decussation
  • Innervates superior oblique muscle
