questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section is shown below. Identify the staining method.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards a diagnosis of syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis. It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, proteinuria, and the clinical presentation given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:

  • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
  • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
  • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
  • Subglottic tracheal stenosis

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was rushed to the ICU following an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There was no history of fever, night sweats or weight loss. MRI scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present.

Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given.

Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are maintained >200/μL for 6 months.

Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts. 

Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted diffusion. 

Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions.

questions.text: The common complications that you would expect to be associated with this abnormal placenta are all except
questions.solution:
Preterm labour is not a complication of placenta succenturiata.

The given image depicts placenta succenturiata in which one or more small lobes of placenta may be placed at a distance from main placental margin.

Its complications are -

  • Postpartum haemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Uterine sepsis
  • Polyp formation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition shown below?

choices.text: Histopathology shows excess collagen arranged parallel to each other

questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The histology of keloid scars shows excess, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation (predominantly type 3 collagen).

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factors.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendencies and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment:

  • Pressure- local moulds or elastic garments
  • Silicone gel sheeting
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage
Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial May be familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Sex Equal in both More common in females
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surfaces) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text: An X-ray of a patient with a history of tibial fracture 9-months back is given below. Which type of non-union is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows hypertrophic non-union of the tibia.

Although the enlarged fracture ends suggest active osteogenesis, the gap is not bridged because of inadequate stability. Such non-unions have adequate vascularity and display abundant callus.

Based on the biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic: Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site. The blood supply is typically poor. On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction. 
  • Oligotrophic: There is minimal callus formation, often due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces. On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction.
  • Hypertrophic: These fractures have an adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur. On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation with an intervening dark area of fibrocartilage-lacking mineral. It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization. 

Pseudoarthrosis has features of hypertrophic nonunion, but due to excessive and chronic motility, there is the formation of a pseudo-capsule containing fluid similar to an actual synovial joint.

questions.text: An undernourished child is brought for consultation. You prescribe a mineral supplement that is absorbed by the mechanism shown in the image below. Identify the supplement.
questions.solution:
The given image shows iron absorption and transport from a duodenal enterocyte into the blood, hence the mineral supplement prescribed can be identified as an iron supplement.

The following image shows in detail, the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte.

Dietary iron is available in two forms - heme and non-heme iron. Initially, the ferric non-heme iron is reduced to ferrous iron by duodenal cytochrome B (ferric reductase) or by vitamin C. The reduced ferrous iron is then transferred into the enterocyte by DMT 1 (divalent metal transporter). 

Heme iron moves into the cytoplasm with the help of transporters. Here, it is metabolized to release ferrous iron, which then follows the same pathway as non-heme iron.

Once inside the enterocyte, it can either get stored as ferritin or transferred across the basolateral membrane by ferroportin. In the plasma, iron is transported in the Fe3+ form bound to transferrin, which is a transport protein. Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+ before it is transported.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby iron absorption too. Thus, iron is trapped in the intestinal cells which is eventually sloughed off. Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from macrophages by binding to ferroportin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: A 45 year old iron smelter, presents to the OPD with history of rice water diarrhoea. The image shows the clinical finding that the doctor notes during examination. Which of the following clinical features would be consistent with the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning. Tremors are consistent with a diagnosis of arsenic poisoning which should be suspected in a patient of with Aldrich Mees lines, red velvety mucosa, and rice water stools.

Hyperpyrexia, Hyperpigmentation, and Anorexia are associated features.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

choices.text: Free immunisation for under 5 year children
Provides free of cost master health check up services

questions.solution:
Suraksha clinic is to provide services in relation to sexually transmitted and genital tract infections.

Facilities provided in Suraksha clinic are:

  • Blood sample testing

It was established under NACO (National Aids Control Organisation) program.

questions.text: Identify the following line shown in the below picture:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Ohngren's line. It is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible. It is used for the classification of maxillary carcinoma.

Growth situated above the plane (supra structure) tends to be more aggressive and poorly differentiated and has a poor prognosis. Growth situated below the plane (infrastructure) is more amenable to treatment and has a better prognosis.

Other options:

Option A: Proper alignment of the face is determined by the Frankfort plane, a horizontal line bisecting the inferior border of the infraorbital rim and the superior border of the external auditory canal.

Option B: Donaldson's line passes through the horizontal semicircular canal and bisects the posterior canal. It is the landmark for the endolymphatic sac which lies anterior and inferior to it. 

ELS: Endolymphatic sac, HSCC: Horizontal semicircular canal, PSCC: Posterior semicircular canal, PF dura: Posterior fossa dura

Option C: Ledermann’s classification uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau, one passes through the floor of the orbit and another passes through the floor of the maxillary antra dividing the face into supra structure (ethmoid, sphenoid, frontal sinuses, and the olfactory area of nose), mesostructure (maxillary sinus and respiratory part of nose) and infrastructure (alveolar process). It is used to classify maxillary carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil
The vision is normal in right eye
Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes

questions.solution:
The given image of "swinging flashlight test" shows both pupils constricting when the left eye is stimulated (normal response) followed by both pupils abnormally dilating when the right eye is stimulated (abnormal response).

This finding is suggestive of Marcus Gunn pupil which is also known as Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).

In this patient the right eye is defective (Option A) and the left eye is normal (rules out option B).

Marcus Gunn pupil refers to the paradoxical response of the pupil to light and it is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease such as optic neuritis or optic nerve damage in glaucoma.It is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex in one eye.

Normal response to stimulation of the eye is constriction of the pupil of the stimulated eye (direct light reflex) and also of the contralateral eye (indirect or consensual light reflex).

Causes of RAPD:

  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g.All types of optic neuritis, glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)
  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )

The below given image depicts the findings seen in Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD).

Option A:Argyl Robertson pupil is seen in neurosyphilis. In this condition,on light stimulation both the pupils will not constrict, but on accommodation (near target) both the pupils will constrict.

Argyll Robertson pupil is attributed to a dorsal midbrain lesion of neurosyphilis that affects the pupillary light pathway but spares the more ventrally placed pupillary near reflex pathway(Accomdation pathway), thereby causing a light-near dissociation.

Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) include:

  • Bilateral small, irregular pupils in dim light
  • Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP)- The eye accomdates by constricting the pupil for a near target.
  • Light Reflex absent: pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light.
  • Cocaine eye drops(mydriatics) induced mydriasis.

questions.text: The following image shows the normal electrophoresis of serum proteins. Which of the following bands is much prominent in nephrotic syndrome ?
questions.solution:
The band that is marked as C in the given image corresponds to α2 globulin. This band becomes much prominent in nephrotic syndrome.

α2  macroglobulin, being a relatively bigger protein compared to others is not lost through urine in nephrotic syndrome. Hence the α2 band which includes α2 macroglobulin is very prominent in serum protein electrophoresis of a nephrotic syndrome patient.

The following image shows the bands with their corresponding proteins in normal serum electrophoresis.

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

questions.text: Which of the following drugs produce this?
questions.solution: The above image shows blackish discolouration of the nail which occurs with hydroxyurea. This phenomenon called melanonychosis is observed with most of the anticancer drugs like taxanes.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect in a patient with sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Thrombocytosis is seen in sickle cell anemia, not thrombocytopenia. Laboratory findings of sickle cell anemia include:

  • Peripheral blood smear:
    • Irreversibly sickled cells (5–50% of red cells)
    • Reticulocytosis (10–25%)
    • Nucleated red blood cells
    • Howell–Jolly bodies and target cells (due to hyposplenism)
  • Granulocytosis - WBC count of 12,000–15,000/mcL
  • Reactive thrombocytosis 
  • High indirect bilirubin levels

questions.text: Identify the period during which twinning results in the type of gestation shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shows monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestation which is seen with twinning between the 9th and 12th  day after fertilisation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the Schultze method of placental separation?

choices.text: The separation begins at the centre of the placenta.
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
There is a formation of retroplacental clot.

questions.solution:
The below image A shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

The process of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Consequently, this central part descends first and becomes visible at the vulva. During this phase, blood gathers in a membranous sac located behind the placenta, resulting in the creation of a retroplacental clot. Bleeding does not happen until the placenta is fully expelled

Mathews-Duncan method:

Placental separation begins at the periphery of the placenta, leading to the maternal surface becoming visible first. Blood gathers between the membranes and the uterine wall and is discharged through the vagina. Unlike the previous method, there is no development of a retroplacental clot, resulting in significant bleeding during this type of placental separation. However, it is less frequent compared to the Schultze method.

questions.text: An obstructive lesion at which of the following levels will cause only expiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi (D) will cause expiratory stridor.

Other options:

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the practice shown in the below image is ________

choices.text: It reduces risk of hospital-acquired infection
It is not a part of warm chain
It can be done by fathers also
It increases rates of breast feeding

questions.solution:
Kangaroo mother care (as shown in the image) is a part of warm chain transportation of babies, especially when incubator ambulances are not available for transportation of the baby.  

Kangaroo discharge - Early discharge from hospital has been shown to cause reduced rates of hospital-acquired infections.

Kangaroo care is a part of the BFHI - Baby-Friendly Hospitals Initiative

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis inferred from the given clinical images is?
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive condition where the absorption of zinc is defective by the intestinal epithelial cell. Affected infants respond dramatically to zinc supplementation.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with jejunojejunostomy.

Option D: Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with post-pregnancy hearing loss. The audiogram shows conductive deafness along with Carhart's notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These findings are highly suggestive of otosclerosis. 

Ototoxicity, Meniere’s disease, and noise-induced hearing loss cause sensory neural hearing loss (SNHL) and not conductive hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fistula ante fenestrae.

The presence of a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, known as the Schwartze sign, suggests an active focus. PTA shows loss of air conduction with air-bone gap, more for lower frequencies and Carhart's notch may be seen. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage. Definitive treatment is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Carhart notch usually disappears after a successful stapedectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

Option B: In Meniere's disease, pure tone audiometry shows an SNHL pattern with a rising curve in the early stages (as lower frequencies are involved first) and as the disease progresses higher frequencies are involved, the curve becomes flat or a falling type.

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 4000 Hz both for air and bone conduction.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: The cross-section of the brain of an 84-year-old man with dyslipidemia is given below, in comparison with a normal brain. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change?
questions.solution:
The given image shows narrowing of gyri and widening of sulci in a senile brain, which is suggestive of senile atrophy. It is due to a gradual decrease in blood supply as a result of atherosclerosis, known as ischemic atrophy.

The various types of pathological atrophy are:

Pathologic atrophy 
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the sewage treatment shown in the image below?

choices.text: Desludging must be done at least once a year
Anaerobic digestion occurs inside the tank
Soap and disinfectants like phenol should not be used inside the tank

questions.solution:
The given image is of a septic tank. It is not useful for very large communities and is used for household sewage treatment.

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

Below is an image of a double-chambered septic tank.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin finding. You would advise supplementation with which of the following?

choices.text: Vitamin B complex and vitamin K
Safflower oil and vitamin B complex

questions.solution:
The image shows rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

Phrynoderma or toad skin is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin E, B, A, C, and essential fatty acids.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the dermatology OPD with findings as shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs can result in this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The above presentation is of livedo reticularis, which is an adverse effect of amantadine.

The patient presents with a common skin finding consisting of a mottled vesicular pattern that appears as a lace-like purplish discoloration of the skin which is due to the local release of catecholamines resulting in post-capillary vasoconstriction.

Adverse effects of amantadine are:

  • Insomnia, restlessness, confusion
  • Nightmares
  • Anticholinergic effects
  • Hallucinations 
  • Livedo reticularis
  • Edema of ankles

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below.  Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. 

There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.

It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.text: The ring shown in the image below is a ______________
questions.solution:
NuvaRing is a hormonal contraceptive that releases ethinyl estradiol and etonogestrel once inserted into the vagina. The hormones are absorbed through the vaginal epithelium.

The ring is inserted within 5 days of onset of menses and is removed after 3 weeks to allow withdrawal bleeding. After removal, a new ring can be inserted in a week.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a sudden increase in the lesions given in the image. Which of the following should be suspected?
questions.solution:
This image shows seborrheic keratosis. A sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses in association with skin tags and acanthosis nigricans has been associated with a variety of malignancies, including gastrointestinal and lung cancers; it is also known as the Leser-Trélat sign.

Seborrheic keratoses are common epidermal tumors consisting of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They present as well-demarcated, round or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance.

questions.text: The image below shows a gunshot wound on the skull. Identify the type of wound and its features.

choices.text: Exit wound - bevelling of outer table and punched out hole on inner table
Entry wound - bevelling of inner table and punched out hole on outer table
Entry wound - bevelling of outer table and punched out hole on inner table
Exit wound - bevelling of inner table and punched out hole on outer table

questions.solution:
The given image shows bevelling of the outer table and a punched-out hole on the inner table. Hence, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, then the same pattern occurs, but this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

The marked structure is ligamentum teres, and it is an embryological remnant of the left umbilical vein.

questions.text: Inheritance pattern depicted in the following pedigree chart is:
questions.solution:
In the given pedigree chart females are carriers and only males are affected and males pass it on to all female progenies but not any male progeny. Hence it is X linked disorder.

Since disease is not manifesting in carrier females, it is a recessive disorder.

Hence this is an X linked recessive inheritance.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given image showing thickening of tissues in the temporal and orbital regions with coarse overlying skin suggests a diagnosis of plexiform neurofibroma.

Plexiform neurofibroma represents an uncommon variant (30%) of neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1). Plexiform neurofibromas are usually evident at birth and result from a diffuse thickening of nerve trunks and surrounding tissues that are usually located in the orbital or temporal region of the face. The skin overlying it may be coarse and associated with hyperpigmentation.

Plexiform neurofibromas may produce an overgrowth of an extremity and a deformity of the corresponding bone.

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules >5mm in prepubertal and >15mm in postpubertal
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris lisch nodules
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones with or without pseudoarthrosis.
  • Optic gliomas
  • A first-degree relative with NF-1

questions.text: The following process where transportation is along the concentration gradient is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to a lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion. 

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Glucose transporters also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions inside the cell membrane by binding to a carrier/ transport protein. 

For example, insulin stimulates glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane. This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues. 

Other options - 

Option A. Simple diffusion - It is along the concentration gradient but is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Option C. Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against a membrane with chemical or electrical gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option D. In secondary active transport, the active transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances. Examples include the symport of sodium with glucose (luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine), and Ca2+ in the cardiac muscle cells.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

Related Pearl: Glucose transporters and their locations

GLUT 2

GLUT 3
Neurons, kidney, placenta High affinity for glucose
GLUT 4
Heart, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue Insulin-dependent glucose uptake
GLUT 5

GLUT 8
Blastocyst, testis, brain Insulin-dependent glucose uptake in blastocyst. Transports glucose to Mature spermatozoa.
GLUT 9

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with progressive worsening of vision. He said that he has been having recurrent falls lately. MRI brain showed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI images (midsagittal) show the hummingbird sign. The clinical features of this patient combined with the MRI findings are suggestive of progressive supranuclear palsy. It occurs due to characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with relative preservation of the pons. 

Progressive supranuclear palsy is also known as Steele–Richardson–Olszewski syndrome. It is characterized by:

  • Slow ocular saccades
  • Eyelid apraxia
  • Restricted eye movements
  • Downward gaze is predominantly impaired
  • Early gait disturbance and falls

Tau deposition most prominent in subcortical structures is seen.

The MRI image below shows the hummingbird sign:

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the marked opening?
questions.solution:
The marked opening in the muscular part of the diaphragm is that of the esophagus. Vagus nerve passes through it. 

Oesophageal opening passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm at the level of T10 vertebra.

questions.text: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. 

All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.

questions.text: The degree of prolapse shown in the image given below is _______
questions.solution: The image shows external os lying at the level of introitus. Hence it is second degree uterine prolapse.

questions.text: The following image shows the chest X-ray of a preterm neonate who was admitted to the NICU in view of severe respiratory distress.  What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture of respiratory distress in a premature neonate and the X-ray findings of diffuse ground-glass (reticulo-granular) opacities with a characteristic white-out appearance, hyaline membrane disease (HMD) is the most likely diagnosis.

HMD, also known as neonatal Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a relatively common condition resulting from insufficient production of surfactant that occurs in preterm neonates. Maternal diabetes, perinatal asphyxia, and multiple gestations are other known risk factors for the condition. Clinical features include tachypnea, chest retractions, expiratory grunting, and nasal flaring. The infant may or may not be cyanosed. 

X-ray features of HMD include:

  • Air bronchogram sign
  • Diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • Obliteration of cardiac and diaphragmatic contours giving rise to 'white-out' lung (indicates severe disease)

 

Chest radiograph (A) shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

questions.text: A 3-month-old male child was brought with a history of fever and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia, a chest X-ray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent of pneumonia in an infant with X-ray showing pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma) is Staphylococcus aureus.

In newborns and infants, S. aureus is a significant cause of severe respiratory tract infections, presenting with dyspnea, fever, and respiratory failure. Community-acquired infections are often preceded by viral infections, most commonly influenza. Among adults, nosocomial S. aureus pulmonary infections are frequently observed in intubated patients within intensive care units.

S. aureus often causes necrotizing pneumonitis that may be associated with complications such as pneumothorax and empyema.

Pneumatocoele can also be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, E. coli, group A streptococci, Klebsiella pneumoniae, etc. However, Staphylococcus aureus is most commonly implicated.

Other options:

Option A: Klebsiella pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. Patients present with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum. Classic chest X-ray findings include upper lobe consolidation, classically on the right side, cavitation, and bulging fissure sign.

The following image shows bulging fissure sign: 

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia. Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. On examination, the involved lobes are dull to percussion, bronchial breath sounds, and crackles are heard on auscultation. 

The following image shows right lower lobe consolidation:

Option C: Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are heard. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis.

The below chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery:

questions.text: Immunohistochemistry for HER2 protein expression is performed in 3 patients with breast carcinoma, with the following results. Which of the following patients should be subjected to fluorescence in-situ hybridization?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferential staining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining. Hence, she should be subjected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm HER2-positive gene amplification status.

The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors:

  • Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed).
  • Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISH

Once HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated with trastuzumab or lapatinib. 

Related Pearl: Newer molecular tests in breast cancer

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy. These are:

  • Oncotype Dx (21-geneassay)
  • Mammaprint (70-gene assay)
  • EndoPredict (12-gene assay)
  • PAM50 (50-gene assay)

Oncotype Dx can only be used in hormone (ER, PR) receptor-positive cancers, while mammaprint can be used in both hormone receptor (ER, PR) positive and hormone receptor-negative cancers. 

These tests are used for T1,2 N0 M0 breast cancers – (node-negative, metastasis-negative). Using these molecular tests, a recurrence score (0 – 100) is calculated.

  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy
  • If the score is high, then chemotherapy should be added

questions.text: Which of the following images correctly represent the regulation of growth hormone secretion?
questions.solution:
Option C represents the correct regulation of growth hormone secretion.

Following inferences can be made out from the image given as option C.

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone secreted from the hypothalamus acts on the anterior pituitary to release growth hormone.
  • The released growth hormone increases the circulating levels of IGF -1 which exerts its effect on the tissues.
  • Ghrelin promotes the secretion of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary.
  • Somatostatin secreted from the hypothalamus hs an inhibitory effect on the GH secretion from the anterior pituitary.
  • Similarly, IGF -1 exerts negative feedback on GH secretion and positive feedback on somatostatin secretion, which in turn inhibits GH secretion.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive man on cART is presented with the following finding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fat redistribution resulting in the classic buffalo hump appearance. Nelfinavir is the most likely cause.

It is a protease inhibitor and its chronic administration can result in fat redistribution and metabolic syndrome. 

Note: Atazanavir has the least propensity to cause lipodystrophy and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

Related Pearl: Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: A patient with leprosy, who has completed a course of multi-drug therapy, presents with complaints of developing painful, tender, and raised lesions on his forehead recently as shown in the image below. What is the first-line treatment for him?

choices.text: Restart multi drug therapy and start thalidomide
Restart multi drug therapy and start prednisolone

questions.solution:
The presence of new erythematous and tender subcutaneous nodules in a patient with leprosy indicates that he has developed type II lepra reaction. It is also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) and the first line of treatment is prednisolone.

Multi-drug therapy (MDT) should not be restarted in patients who develop lepra reactions after the completion of treatment.

Prednisolone is started at a dose of 40 mg per day and gradually tapered by 5 mg every 2 weeks. 'Prednisolone card' is given when treatment is started. If the patient becomes steroid-dependent, then clofazimine is added.

The  key targets of the Global Leprosy Strategy 2021-2023 announced by WHO (Accelerating towards a leprosy-free world) are:

  • 120 countries reporting zero new autochthonous cases.
  • 70% reduction in the annual number of new cases detected.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million population of new cases with Grade 2 disability.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million children of new child cases with leprosy.

The current goal is the elimination of leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the organism given in the image below?

choices.text: It is an uncommon pathogenic protozoan in the human intestines
Cysts can survive in water for upto 3 months
It has hooks on the ventral surface to adhere to the intestines
The cysts contain 2 nuclei in mature form

questions.solution:
The image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia and the cysts can survive in water for up to 3 months.

Other options:

  • It is the only common pathogenic protozoan in the human intestines.
  • The trophozoites are heart-shaped and have a concave sucking disk on the ventral surface to adhere to the intestines.
  • The cysts are ellipsoid, thick-walled and contain 4 nuclei in mature form and 2 nuclei in the immature form.

questions.solution:
The image given represents propagated epidemic which results from "person to person transmission".

Eg: Food poisoning, Measles, Chickenpox, Cholera, Bhopal Gas tragedy

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with blurred vision, photophobia, and increasing pain in his right eye. He has been using contact lenses for the past 2 years. He mentions swimming with his cousins 2 weeks back in a local pond. A close-up image of the eye is given below. What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
The history of a patient with contact lens use with swimming in freshwater ponds with the image depicting a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) makes acanthamoeba keratitis the likely diagnosis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare protozoal infection of the cornea. It is more common in soft contact lens users. The organism exists either as active, motile trophozoites or dormant, double-walled cysts. Suspicious sources of infection can be swimming or use of the hot tub while wearing contact lenses, homemade saline solution to wash contact lenses, exposure to standing groundwater etc.

Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as ring lesion (most common), pseudo-dendrites and as a reticular pattern.

Diagnosis:

  • Confocal microscopy - may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms
  • Histopathology - double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff
  • Culture - Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. coli plated on a non-nutrient agar

questions.text: The following is an RBC from venous blood. Identify the “?” in the image.
questions.solution:
Cl- ion is exchanged for HCO3- across the RBC membrane.

The diagram explains the chloride shift that occurs in an RBC of venous blood as it carries CO2 to the lungs. This shift is mediated by an anion exchanger called AE 1 (Band 3). When this occurs, the osmolality inside an RBC is increased due to the chloride ions. This causes RBCs to absorb more water and swell up which accounts for the increased PCV in venous blood compared to the arterial blood.

questions.text: Identify the device given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chemoport.

Chemoports are implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Internal jugular veins and subclavian veins are the commonly used access veins for port placement. These devices are usually retained for a period of 1 to 2 years or more after which the device is explanted.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given condition is lupus pernio which is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis.

Lupus pernio is a chronic inflammatory skin lesion, which is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks and often is purple in color.

Other options:

Option A: Acne rosacea is a skin disorder with onset in middle‐aged adults (30–50 years old) and involves the convexities of the face.

Option C: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option D: Malar rash or butterfly rash is classically seen in SLE.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique.
questions.solution:
The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought with complaints of premature development of breast buds. The sagittal MRI of the brain revealed a hypothalamic hamartoma. All of the following are used in the treatment of this patient, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central precocious puberty. GnRH antagonists are not used in the treatment of this patient.

Precocious puberty is defined as the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years in girls.

There are two types of precocious puberty:

  • Central/GnRH-dependent precocious puberty
  • Peripheral/GnRH-independent precocious puberty

Hypothalamic hamartomas are a neuronal migration defect that is the common cause of organic central precocious puberty. These lesions are believed to cause precocious puberty through the endogenous pulsatile release of GnRH, either independently or in concert with the GnRH-secreting neurons of the hypothalamus. 

Treatment of central precocious puberty:

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implants) are the treatment of choice for tumor-induced central precocious puberty.
  • Inj. depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) 100–200 mg, IM every 2–4 weeks to induce regression of these premature changes and cessation of menstruation.
  • Cyproterone acetate exerts antiandrogenic and antigonadotropin effects and is effective in treatment.
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (gamma knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image?

choices.text: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
It cannot be detected by sonography
It is diagnosed usually after delivery
Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension

questions.solution:
The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed against the fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography.

In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetus continues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes:

Outcome Type
Disappears Vanishing twin
Gets compressed Fetus compressus
Flattened through desiccation Fetus papyraceus

Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin:

  • Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in the surviving twin
  • Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity in the surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses.
  • Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin
  • Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demise

Death in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. The surviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise.

questions.text: Identify the marked finding in a patient who underwent cataract surgery.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Soemmering’s ring. It is defined as a thick ring of after cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction. No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear.

If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius ring – Formed after blunt trauma as a circular brown ring on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule.

Option C: Weiss or Vogt’s ring – It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring – It refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with severe right upper quadrant pain for 8 hours associated with nausea and vomiting. A diagnosis of acute cholecystitis was made and he underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The specimen is shown below. This finding is associated with all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows pigmented gallstones, which are not associated with hyperlipidemia syndromes.

Pigmented gallstones are made of bilirubin and calcium salts. They can occur in:

  • Chronic hemolytic syndromes
  • Ileal resection
  • Biliary infection
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

Cholesterol stones are made of crystalline cholesterol monohydrates. Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the cells marked in the gastric gland shown below?
questions.solution:
The cell marked ‘C’ is the enterochromaffin-like cell that secretes histamine. It has receptors for gastrin.

The structure marked ‘A’ is the region of the isthmus of a gastric gland. Mucous neck cells and stem cells are present in this region.

The structure marked ‘B’ is the parietal cell (oxyntic cell). It is characterized by the presence of canaliculi. The cell has numerous mitochondria because it is actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid.

The structure marked ‘C’ is the enterochromaffin-like cell (ECL). It is identified by its location in the subepithelial region. Function of this cell is to release histamine which in turn stimulates the parietal cells to secrete HCL. The ECL is stimulated by gastrin secreted by G cells from the pylorus and acetylcholine secreted by the vagus.

The structure marked ‘D’ are the chief cells. These cells are identified by their location towards the base of the gland. These cells secrete pepsinogen by exocytosis which are stored inside the cell as zymogen granules.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted to the ICU, however he died soon after. What is the following finding seen in the patient's post-mortem brain samples known as?
questions.solution:
Fever, neurological symptoms like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies. The given image thus represents Negri bodies seen in post-mortem brain samples of patients with rabies. 

Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies.

The image below shows Negri bodies:

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient is being evaluated for longstanding anemia. On clinical examination, you notice the given finding. Which of the following metal poisoning is associated with this characteristic finding?
questions.solution:
The image is showing characteristic Burtonian lines, which are seen in lead poisoning and mercury poisoning.

These are bluish-grey gingival lead lines that occur with chronic exposure to lead poisoning.

The image given below shows Burtonian lines on the gums.

questions.text: In the given image, the perineal membrane is denoted by:
questions.solution:
In the given image of a median sagittal section of a male perineum, the perineal membrane is denoted by the arrow marked as C.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into:

  • A deep perineal space lying above it
  • A superficial perineal space lying below it

It has a distinct dorsal and a ventral portion, which are closely connected with Levator ani.
The dorsal portion is related to the support of the perineal body and lateral vaginal wall by its attachment to the ischiopubic ramus. The ventral portion, on the other hand, is contiguous with the structures supporting urethra.

The marked membranes in the given image are as follows:

questions.text: The test performed in the following video is
questions.solution:
The test performed in the given video is Allen's test.

Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Procedure:

  • The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded as the patient makes a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.
  • Then the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation:

  • As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the color of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5 – 6 seconds.
  • If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.
  • The modified Allen’s test considers a threshold of 5 to 15 seconds.

Clinical significance:

  • In recent years, studies have shown that, although the Allen test is often used to identify patients at increased risk for ischemic complications from radial artery cannulation, the predictive value of this test is poor.
  • It is also used for identifying patients acceptable for radial artery harvest or use for coronary angiography.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with diabetes presents with complaints of dark floating spots and flashes of light in her left eye. Optical coherence tomography of the left eye is given in the image below. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
The image shows vitreomacular traction with detached posterior vitreous membrane and foveal traction. 

OCT images:

1. Normal OCT

 

2. Vitreomacular traction- The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as indicated by the arrow. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion may also be seen at the site of traction.

 

3. Vitreomacular adhesion- posterior vitreous detachment but no macular or foveal traction. The retinal morphology is normal.

 

4. Macular hole - a partial or full-thickness retinal defect is seen.

A full-thickness macular hole is seen in the image below.

 

5. Central serous retinopathy- fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment. 

 

6. Cystoid macular edema - loss of foveal depression with cystoid spaces in the retina.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. He gives a history of consumption of alcohol. On examination the following findings were observed on the abdomen. His serum amylase and lipase are elevated 3 times from the baseline. Identify the correct pair.

choices.text: A-Cullen's sign, B- Sister Mary Joseph nodule
A- Cullen's sign, B-Grey Turner's sign
A-Grey turner's sign, B- Sister Mary Joseph nodule

questions.solution:
Abdominal pain after consumption of alcohol, elevated lipase and amylase suggest acute pancreatitis. In necrotizing pancreatitis, there is bruising of skin seen as

  • A-Grey turner's sign: Bruising in the flanks
  • B-Cullen's sign: Periumbilical bruising

Sister Mary Joseph nodule also called Sister Mary Joseph sign, refers to a palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus as a result of metastasis of malignant cancer in the pelvis or abdomen.
