questions.text: A 60-year-old patient’s thyroid scan is given below. Which of the following is the preferred next step of management?
questions.solution:
The radionuclide scan shows the presence of an isolated cold nodule. Cold nodules have a high risk of developing a malignancy. Therefore the preferred next step of management would be Ultrasound-guided FNA biopsy.  

Propylthiouracil, Propranolol, and Radioactive thyroid ablation are used for hot nodules.

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelography (IVP) depicts the cobra head or adder head deformity or spring onion sign seen in bilateral ureterocele. These signs refer to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa.

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural portion of the ureter, more commonly seen in females than males. It is thought to be caused due to ureteric orifice atresia. They are similar to ectopic ureters, which typically drain the upper pole of the kidney and are associated with dysplastic or non-functional renal tissue.

If they present clinically, ureteroceles often manifest with urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children, while in adults, they are more likely to present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’, ‘adder head’, or 'spring onion sign'.  On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the ER after a skateboarding accident during which he had fallen with head hitting the ground first. He has a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a tissue paper. The investigation of choice for localizing the site is:
questions.solution:
HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea. History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to the OPD by her mother as she noticed some deformity in the hip and lower limbs of the child. On examination,  asymmetry of groin crease is seen and the following test in the image is positive. What is the name of the test being performed?
questions.solution:
Galeazzi's test is shown in the above image.

It is done in children with unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) between 3 to 8 months of age.

The child is placed supine with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both the knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen to be at a lower level indicating femoral shortening. This is also known as Alli's sign.

Tests for DDH are:

  • Barlow's test
  • Ortolani's test
  • Galeazzi's test
  • Asymmetric skin fold test

Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In this test, direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.

questions.text: The following image shows the reabsorption and secretion of various ions. In which part of the nephron is this seen?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a portion of the late distal convoluted tubule. This can be identified by the following features represented in the diagram:

  • Presence of two distinct types of cells, the principal cells, and intercalated cells.
  • The principal cells are identified by the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium into the lumen.
  • The intercalated cells are identified by the absorption of potassium with the secretion of hydrogen ions into the lumen.
  • Presence of water absorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)

Note that these features are also seen in the collecting duct. The late distal tubule and collecting duct are similar anatomically and functionally.

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration or osmolarity remains the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.

The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- by a Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter. Some of the K+ that is reabsorbed leaks back into the lumen, creating a potential difference with more positivity in the lumen. This lumen positivity is responsible for the absorption of divalent ions like Ca+2 and Mg+2. The thick ascending limb is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.

Early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) reabsorbs Na+ and Cl- by the Na+-Cl- co-transporter. This segment is also impermeable to water. Because of the relative solute reabsorption, there is dilution of the tubular fluid.

The late distal tubule and collecting duct have two kinds of cells as mentioned above. Principal cells reabsorb Na+ and secrete K+ into the lumen. The Na+ reabsorption is through epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC). The expression of ENaC is mediated by aldosterone and thus increases whenever there is activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The absorption of Na+ is balanced by the secretion of K+ into the lumen.

The water permeability of the principal cells is controlled by ADH. When ADH levels are high, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of the principal cells, leading to water reabsorption.

Intercalated cells reabsorb K+ and secrete H+ by an H+-K+ counter-transporter. They also have an H+ pump which is responsible for acid secretion.

Related Pearl: Summary of Transport Across Proximal and Distal Portions of the Nephron

Proximal Tubule
Reabsorption

Secretion 

67% of filtered Na+ actively reabsorbed, not subject to control; Cl– follows passively

All filtered glucose and amino acids reabsorbed by secondary active transport; not subject to control

Variable amounts of filtered PO43- and other electrolytes reabsorbed; subject to control

65% of filtered H2O osmotically reabsorbed; not subject to control

50% of filtered urea passively reabsorbed; not subject to control

Almost all filtered K+ reabsorbed; not subject to control

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Organic ion secretion; not subject to control
Distal tubule
Reabsorption Secretion

Variable Na+ reabsorption, controlled by aldosterone; Cl– follows passively

Variable H2O reabsorption, controlled by vasopressin

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Variable K+ secretion, controlled by aldosterone

questions.text: An 80-year-old man who is a known smoker presented with complaints of fatigue, flank pain, and bipedal edema. Serum biochemistry showed an increase in liver enzyme values and urine microscopy was suggestive of microscopic hematuria. CT abdomen is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and CT is suggestive of Renal cell carcinoma presenting with Stauffer syndrome.

Stauffer syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome seen in Renal cell carcinoma. It is a non metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6.

Stauffer syndrome is characterised by

  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Raised Alkaline phosphatase
  • Hypergammaglobilinemia
  • Prolonged prothrombin time

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient presents with sore throat, fever and lymphadenopathy. Paul-Bunnell test returns positive. Which of the following is true regarding the image given?

choices.text: B cells infected by the causative organism can be seen
Reactive B cells can be seen
Reactive T cells can be seen
Myelocytes and metamyelocytes can be seen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a teenager with  and a positive Paul-Bunnell test is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis/glandular fever. The peripheral blood smear image shows atypical lymphocytes, also called as Downey Type 2 cells, which are reactive T-cells. 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), also called Human Herpesvirus Type 4, is the causative organism for infectious mononucleosis, which is a lymphoproliferative disease transmitted by direct contact, commonly by saliva. 

The virus infects nasopharyngeal epithelial cells, salivary and lymphoid tissues by binding to the CD21 receptors. Latent infection of B cells, induces B-cell mitogenesis and results in the production of atypical reactive EBV specific CD8+ T cells (Downey cells). The B-cells produce antibodies that are reative to horse and sheep erythrocytes, called Heterophile antibodies, which are detected by the Paul-Bunnell or monospot test, which is one of the diagnostic tests for the disease.

Patients present with sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy and often splenomegaly associated with significant lymphocytosis. The diagnosis is usually based on the presence of atypical lymphocytes, a positive Paul-Bunnell test and positive titres of viral capsid antigen or EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) on ELISA. Early infection induces IgM formation, and later specific IgG which exists for life.

The disease is usually self-limiting and treatment is supportive in nature as in other viral infectious diseases.

Other conditions caused by EBV infection include:

  • Hairy oral leukoplakia
  • Burkitt lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of black stools and black coated tongue as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is implicated?
questions.solution:
Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate is known to cause blackening of the tongue, dentures and stools.

It combines with trace amounts of sulfur in saliva and colon to form bismuth sulfide. Bismuth sulfide is a highly insoluble black salt. The adverse effect is claimed to be temporary and harmless.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Identify the organism & the stain seen in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Helicobacter pylori stained using Warthin-Starry stain.

H.pylori is a Gram-negative spiral rod that is motile by a unipolar tuft of lophotrichous flagella. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade into the mucosa.

The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

questions.text: Based on your observation of the foot of the patient shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis and its inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
The given image shows periungual fibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis. Periungual fibromas are benign tumors that are composed of connective tissue and typically appear in the second decade of life or later.

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder. It is inherited in autosomal dominant pattern.

The clinical features include:

  • Ash-leaf macules - hypopigmented macules -
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Shagreen patches mostly over the lower back
  • Periungual fibromas

The image below shows an ash leaf macule.

The image below shows a Shagreen patch.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
Antibodies against hemidesmosomes is the false statement as the given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris. The antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmogleins 1 and 3.

This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

The first-line investigation in pemphigus vulgaris is the Tzanck smear. It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.

 

Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the lower leg as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.

Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation.

Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

questions.text: Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows multicellular, pear-shaped macroconidia, arranged in clusters, seen in genus Epidermophyton.

questions.text: Which of the following anticonvulsants most commonly produces the following side effect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gum hypertrophy which is commonly seen with phenytoin.

This can be prevented by maintaining good oral hygiene.

Other side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly)

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

questions.text: The following used equipment is discarded into which of the following containers according to Bio-Medical Waste Management guidelines 2018?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Foley’s catheter and it is discarded into red bin according to Bio-Medical Waste management guidelines 2018.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is T1 weighted.

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white whereas In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark.

FLAIR: Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. So, CSF is dark, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. The image is given below.

Short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) is an inversion-recovery technique that nulls fat. So, fat is black. It is done to detect bone marrow edema. The image is shown below.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is this type of scale characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows a collarette scale which is a fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.Pityriasis rosea is an acute self‐limiting disease affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms. It is associated with human herpesvirus 7 and 6 (HHV-7 & HHV-6).

Appearance of scales:

  • Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk or neck covered by fine scales
  • After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in colour and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales.
  • It is followed by a marginal collarete of scale with a central clearing. The scales are attached peripherally with the free edges attached internally. It is also called hanging curtain sign
  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of cleavage parallel to the ribs in a christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

Option A: Annular lesions with central clearing and peripheral scaling, associated with severe itching are characteristic of tinea corporis. 

Option D: In icthyosis vulgaris, dry, fine fish-like scales are noted. 

Option B: Seborrheic dermatitis shows red, itchy flaky scales over the scalp and other seborrheic areas.

The image below shows a Herald patch.

questions.text: A patient suffers head trauma following which he complains of diplopia. His extraocular motility testing in the 9 gazes is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a left oculomotor nerve palsy.

It is evident by the upper lid ptosis and down and out deviation of the left eye, as seen in the primary position of gaze (central image).

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
The given mage shows the Triangle of Doom.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at the internal ring

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Staples are avoided in this region during hernia repair due to the risk of injury to the vessels which might result in severe hemorrhage.

Option a:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Superiorly by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Option b:

Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle are:

  • Laterally by Inferior epigastric artery
  • Medially by the lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by the inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to the inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters the deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to the inferior epigastric artery)

Option d:

The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line)?
questions.solution:
Curve C corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line). The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the left relative to the adult curve.

The fetal hemoglobin (Hb F) has a greater affinity for O2 than adult hemoglobin (Hb A). This facilitates the movement of O2 from the mother to fetus. The cause of this greater affinity is the poor binding of 2,3-DPG by ɣ polypeptide chains that replace β chains in Hb F. The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is thus shifted to the left relative to the adult curve. Typically, fetal arterial Po2 is low, hence leftward shift enhances placental uptake of O2.

questions.text: Identify the ionizing radiation -
questions.solution:
The image is of beta rays as it can penetrate paper but stopped by few millimeters of aluminium.

Beta particle is a high energy, high speed electron or positron which can penetrate paper and can be stopped by a few millimetres of aluminium. The range of beta rays depends on their initial energy and electron density of the material.

Typical ranges in tissue are a few millimetres, in air the range may go to several meters. Beta particles cause damage to tissue in a similar manner to alpha rays but less severely.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

questions.text: As an intern posted in the OT, you see the Anesthesia Senior Resident holding the needle shown in the image. What is the likely procedure that he is about to perform?
questions.solution:
The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified

Epidural anesthesia set with Touhy's needle and epidural catheter.

Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: An old cab driver whose livelihood depends on his driving is distressed. He complains that everything appears distorted and he perceives objects to smaller than their usual size. His anterior segment appears normal. Examination of the fundus reveals a honeycomb appearance of the macula. FFA is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is that of fluorescein angiography showing the "flower petal pattern," which is seen in cystoid macular edema (CME). The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer at the macula

The accumulation of fluid in the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer leads to retinal thickening at macula and loss of foveal depression, formation of cystic spaces (honey-comb macula). Risk factors include retinitis pigmentosa, uveitis, niacin, PGE2 analogues, epinephrine in aphakia, diabetic retinopathy, retinal venous occlusion and Irvin-Gass syndrome (CME post-cataract surgery).

Symptoms may include blurring of vision, distortion, and micropsia.

Therapeutic approaches for treating CME depend on the underlying etiology. This includes steroids, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, anti-VEGF agents, PPV for associated vitreomacular traction.

questions.text: While examining a chronic alcoholic patient, you notice the given finding. Which of the following is false regarding it?

choices.text: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
Presence of even 1 lesion is abnormal
Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release

questions.solution:
The given image shows spider telangiectasia and the presence of >2 to 3 of these are considered abnormal.

Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in liver cirrhosis.

Clinical features seen in cirrhosis include:

  • Spider telangiectasias
  • Palmar erythema
  • Terry's nails - pallor of the proximal nail bed
  • Clubbing
  • Gynaecomastia
  • Caput medusae - dilated abdominal veins.
  • Parotid enlargement

The image below shows Terry's nails.

questions.text: Which of the following drug was the first to be approved by USFDA to be used in the following drug delivery system?
questions.solution:
Scopolamine (hyoscine) was the first drug approved as transdermal therapeutic system by USFDA in 1979. It was then marketed for treating motion sickness.

Certain common drugs available as transdermal patch in India include:

  • Nicotine for smoking cessation
  • Oestradiol for HRT
  • GTN for angina
  • Fentanyl for analgesia

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?

choices.text: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: The skin biopsy section was taken from a patient diagnosed with psoriasis is shown below. What is the arrow pointing to?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the arrow points to a small collection of cells seen within the stratum corneum in a patient with psoriasis. This is suggestive of a Munro's microabscess.

Munro's microabscesses are small collections of neutrophil polymorphs. Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis are also seen here.

The spongiform pustule of Kogoj refers to the multilocular micropustules that form in the spinous layer of the epidermis in pustular psoriasis.

Predominant cell

Disease

questions.text: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron.  

Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” 

Option (b):

The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit.

Option (c):

A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure.

Option (d):

A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.

questions.text: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.

Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow. 

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.
  • Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before corrective surgery.
  • Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages.
  • A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: The condition shown below results from an  Aedes aegypti transmitted flaviviral infection during pregnancy. Identify the virus implicated.
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito borne flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti. The symptoms of the infection are similar to dengue and include fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain.

NCDC Delhi and National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below show the transverse section of the uterus and the histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Patients present with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. Diagnosis is usually made with transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) or MR imaging. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presents with the lesions shown below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?

choices.text: Belongs to beta herpes virus group
Latent infection occurs in lymphoid tissue

questions.solution:
The lesions - multiple grouped vesicles on the top lip -  represent cold sores, also known as herpes labialis. It is caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). The true statement is that HSV-1 also causes sporadic acute encephalitis. 

HSV-1 is an alpha herpes virus. It has a short replication cycle (8-16 hours) and establishes latent infection primarily in the trigeminal ganglia. It is the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis in the USA. The infected cells show Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies. 

Herpes labialis, or cold sores, primarily affects the lip and typically presents as thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down with superficial ulcers. They generally heal without scarring. It is a recurrent, episodic disease. HSV-1 can be isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread from cases or carriers. HSV-2 is responsible for the majority of genital herpes infections and is commonly transmitted venereally.

The images below show lesions of herpes labialis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical manifestations of herpes simplex virus-1

  1. Cutaneous lesions:
    • Fever blister
    • Herpetic whitlow
    • Herpetic gladiatorum
    • Eczema herpeticum: A generalised eruption caused by herpes infections in children suffering from eczema
  2. Mucosal (buccal mucosa is the most common site involved):
    • Gingivostomatitis
    • Pharyngitis
    • Recurrent herpes labialis
  3. Ophthalmic: 
    • Follicular conjunctivitis
    • Acute keratoconjunctivitis
  4. Nervous system:
    • HSV encephalitis
    • HSV meningitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a thyroid swelling underwent thyroidectomy and the histopathological examination of the specimen shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen on histopathological examination of a neck swelling in a middle-aged female suggests a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy with a female preponderance and peaking in the 3rd-5th decade.

Risk factors include radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid carcinoma. Mostly, patients are asymptomatic or they might present with a palpable thyroid nodule. It mainly metastasizes through the lymphatic route.

Comprehensive thyroid ultrasound with bilateral central and lateral neck lymph nodes mapping should be done as part of the imaging workup. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI of the neck and chest and intraluminal imaging (laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, or esophagoscopy) may be required in patients with potentially more advanced local and regional disease.

Management includes

  • ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy for a low-risk, unilateral, 1-4 cm tumor without extrathyroidal extension/ evidence of metastatic disease as well as for a tumor that is < 1 cm in size. 
  • total thyroidectomy if high risk of recurrence.

The below image shows orphan Annie eye nuclei-

Histopathological features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin  
  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcified structures within the papillae

 

Other options-

Option B: Follicular carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

 

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma shows large pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and, mixed cells. The below image shows anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the given radiograph showing pedunculated growth in the metaphyseal region projecting away from the epiphysis suggest the diagnosis of osteochondroma. 

Osteochondromas are benign bone tumours that are commonly present in the adolescent age group. They usually present as painless masses in long bones like the femur or humerus. 

They are seen as well-defined bony protuberances, which may be pedunculated or sessile. Pedunculated osteochondromas point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis. The cortex and cancellous bone of osteochondroma blend with that of the host bone. MRI shows a classical cartilaginous cap. Osteochondromas usually grow with skeletal maturity and stop once growth stops.

Osteochondroma can turn into low-grade chondrosarcoma, but the malignant transformation is extremely rare. It should be suspected in the following cases:

  • Growth after skeletal maturity
  • Lucency in the bone
  • Additional scintigraphic activity
  • Cortical destruction
  • Pain after puberty
  • Soft tissue mass
  • Thickened cartilage cap >2 cm

Treatment is not indicated if the lesion does not produce symptoms. Excision can be done for large lesions with local pressure effects.

Other options:

Option A: Enchondroma is an intramedullary tumour of hyaline cartilage. They are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. They are usually seen in individuals aged 20 to 50 years in the tubular bones of the hands and feet. Radiographically, it appears as a central lesion with well-defined, rounded edges and a thin rind of reactive sclerosis.

Option B: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumour and presents as a painful mass that causes effusion or stiffness. On X-rays, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis. The bony cortex is not breached but can appear expanded. The common sites are the ends of long bones. Microscopically, chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix. The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cells, giving the appearance of ‘chicken wire.’

Option D: Giant cell tumour or osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumour. It usually affects young adults, with a peak incidence in the age group of 20–45 years. It presents as a painful mass. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumour. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A young patient presents with resistant hypertension. CT abdomen is shown below. Which of the following conditions may also be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of resistant hypertension and the CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys point to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). One of the manifestations of ADPKD is in the form of Berry aneurysms.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The patients present with hypertension and flank pain. The cause of the pain is the infection of the renal cysts, hemorrhage, or concomitant stone formation. Gross hematuria can also occur when the cyst ruptures. The most important causes of mortality in patients with ADPKD are cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, and infections of the cyst. The patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by late middle age.

Manifestations of ADPKD in other organs include:

  • Cysts in the liver, pancreas, spleen, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Colonic diverticulae
  • Abdominal wall hernias

The diagnosis is made using typical clinical features, family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, and the presence of multiple, bilateral cysts on imaging. Ultrasound is often used as the first-line investigation. CT and T2 weighted MRI are more sensitive than ultrasound in detecting smaller-sized cysts.

Treatment includes strict control of BP using blockers of RAAS, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers. Tolvaptan (vasopressin antagonist), sirolimus, and everolimus (mTOR pathway inhibitors) have been shown to delay the progression of renal disease. More than half of the patients with ADPKD eventually require renal replacement therapy in the form of hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or renal transplant.

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The image shows Marshall Burns's technique used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Baby is allowed to hang by its weight till the nape of the neck is visible
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby is grasped by the ankles
  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction towards the mother's abdomen

Other Options: 

Option A: Pinard’s manoeuvre used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Option B: The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is another method that can be used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Option D: The Ritgen manoeuvre is used for controlled delivery of the head in normal labour.

questions.text: A teenager sustained an injury to his middle finger while attempting to catch a basketball during a match. On examination, his finger appeared as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The extensor tendon is disrupted at the distal interphalangeal joint
Results from a forced extension of the fingertip
Passive extension of the distal interphalangeal joint is preserved
Dorsal hyperextension splints are used in the treatment

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing a flexed fingertip are suggestive of a mallet finger. It results from sudden, forced flexion of the fingertip.

Mallet finger is also known as baseball finger. It is caused by the disruption of the extensor tendon at the distal interphalangeal joint. This leads to unopposed action of flexor tendon resulting in a flexed fingertip. Passive extension of the distal interphalangeal joint is preserved.

Dorsal hyperextension splints are used for immobilization of the joint.

The given image shows a hyperextension splint.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: Identify the following surgical position:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Kraske Position which is also known as Jack-knife position.

The patient's abdomen lies flat upon the bed which is scissored so the hip is lifted and the legs and head are low.

Pilonidal Sinus /Jeep Disease is operated upon in the Jack-knife position.

The sacrococcygeal region is best exposed in the prone jack-knife position with the buttocks taped apart. A paramedian longitudinal incision is made over the abscess cavity that is large enough to allow for adequate drainage and removal of all debris and hair.

Other options:

Fowler and Semi-fowler position:

Fowler's position is a standard patient position in which the patient is seated in a semi-sitting position (45-60 degrees) and may have knees either bent or straight. 

Semi-Fowler, 30 to 45 degrees; and low Fowler, where the head is slightly elevated.

Sims position:

It is used for rectal examination, treatments, and enemas. It is performed by having a patient lie on their left side, left hip and lower extremity straight, and right hip and knee bent. It is also called lateral recumbent position.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper arm and a history of a trivial fall a few days ago. His X-ray is given below. Which of the following is not a treatment modality for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is not a treatment modality used in the treatment of the above condition.
The given X-ray reveals a fracture running through a central cystic lesion situated on the proximal humeral metaphysis, and also shows a fallen fragment sign. This along with the clinical scenario (male within 2nd decade of life) is strongly suggestive of a unicameral bone cyst (simple bone cyst). 

Treatment of simple bone cyst:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions - serial observation with plain radiographs as lesions will regress following skeletal maturity
  • Larger lesions (at risk of pathologic fracture) and symptomatic lesions - 
    • Curettage 
    • Aspiration and injection using:
      • Corticosteroids
      • Bone marrow aspirate
      • Demineralized bone matrix
  • Pathological fractures -
    • Upper limb: managed conservatively as the fracture may initiate cyst healing
    • Lower limb: curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc.

Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: Transection at level 1 with the cutting of the vagal nerve leads to:
questions.solution:
If the vagal nerve is cut along with transection at level 1 i.e. above the level of the pons, then regular breathing with deep inspiration ensues.

Due to the stretching of the lungs during inspiration, impulses are generated in afferent pulmonary vagal fibres. These impulses inhibit inspiratory discharge. Hence, if vagi are cut, the depth of inspiration increases.

Apneusis will occur if the vagus is cut, along with damage to the pneumotaxic centre (Level 2).

Vagi cut

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

B

Mid-pontine level section

Regular breathing continues

Apneusis develops

C

Transection midway between pons and medulla

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

Spontaneous respiration ceases

questions.text: In Kawasaki disease, the following manifestation appears at:
questions.solution:
The above image shows desquamation of skin from fingers and toes. Desquamation of skin from fingers and toes occurs in the subacute phase (2 – 4 weeks) of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: Consider the image given below showing hypertension in community. Number 7 in the image denotes________
questions.solution:
Number 7 in the image denotes diagnosed and treated hypertension.

The above diagram demonstrates the rule of halves of hypertension. It states that only half of the population in developed countries were aware of the condition, only about half of those who were aware of the problem were being treated, and only half of those who were treated were considered adequately treated.

 The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension in community:

questions.text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects

18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness showing the following finding. It was found that the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. He was diagnosed with a hereditary muscular disorder. What is the mode of inheritance in this disorder?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette includes an image of a child with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles along with a history of inability to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease.
  • X-linked recessive mutations of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21.

Clinical features:

  • Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment
  • In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs
  • Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm
  • Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to fibrofatty replacement of muscle
  • Gower's sign: Patients use their arms and hands to walk up their own body from a squatting position due to the reduced strength in the proximal muscles(hip &thigh) of the lower limbs.
  • Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle
  • Inability to walk develops by the age of 10-14 years.
  • Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia after anaesthesia.
  • Death occurs by 3rd decade of life due to respiratory failure.

Note:

Becker's Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) vs. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Mnemonic-

  • BMD: Badly makes dystrophin (defective)
  • DMD: Does not make dystrophin (absent)

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.solution:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
  • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
  • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the tympanogram shown below is true?

choices.text: Normal compliance and a negative pressure

questions.solution:
The tympanogram shown suggests that the tympanic cavity has increased compliance and the intratympanic pressure is normal. It is a type AD curve.

The differential diagnosis for the above tympanogram is:

  • Ossicular discontinuity
  • Thin/lax tympanic membrane

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, the given instrument was used to retract the strap muscles. Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The above image is that of a Langenbeck retractor. It is used for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. 

Option B: Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

Option C: Goligher retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and the upper end of abdominoperineal resection. The retractor is inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel away from the operation site.

Option D: Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for intermediate-type operations, such as:

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

Nail finding

 Associated systemic condition

Clubbing
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)
  • Mesothelioma
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congenital heart disease, Endocarditis

Koilonychia

Iron-deficiency anemia, hemochromatosis, Raynaud’s disease

Psoriasis, Reiter’s syndrome, Alopecia areata

Lymphedema, pleural effusion, immunodeficiency, bronchiectasis, sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, nephrotic syndrome, thyroiditis, tuberculosis, Raynaud’s disease

Nail Pterygium

Dorsal: Lichen Planus

Ventral: trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus

 

Nail finding

Associated systemic condition

Subacute bacterial endocarditis, SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, antiphospholipid syndrome, peptic ulcer disease, malignancies, oral contraceptive use, pregnancy, psoriasis, trauma

Telangiectasia

Rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, dermatomyositis, scleroderma

questions.text: You observe the catheter shown in the image being used by your attending in the ICU. Which of the following procedures is it used for?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-ganz catheter which is used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter. The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. 

Uses of Swan-ganz catheter:

  • Measurement of pressures in right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery
  • Indirect measurement of left atrial pressure through pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Oxygen saturation- pulmonary samples to rule out left-right shunt
  • Monitoring left ventricle filling pressure
  • Differentiate cardiogenic from non cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.text: The lab technician notices a urine sample from a 40 year old male that was normal on collection turning to the colour shown in the image after a few hours. It further darkened over the next few hours. Which of the following statements will not hold true for the patient?

choices.text: Patient should have pain and stiffness of his back
Patient will have history of staining of his clothes by his sweat
Intervertebral space expansion is noted on X-rays
Treatment is initiated with Vitamin C for the patient

questions.solution:
Intervertebral space narrowing, not expansion, is seen in case of Alkaptonuria.

The image shows a urine sample that turned brown on standing and had further darkened later. This is suggestive of Alkaptonuria (Homogentisic aciduria).

The urine contains homogentisic acid which on oxidation and polymerization turns black.

The disease is caused due to deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase, an autosomal recessive disorder.


Other clinical features:-

  • Bluish-black pigmentation of ear cartilage and/or sclera due to deposits of accumulated Homogentisic acid.
  • Pain and stiffness of spine & larger joints - after 3rd decade
  • Staining of clothes by the homogentisic acid in the sweat

The X-Ray shows characteristic intervertebral space narrowing and calcification.
Treatment is with Vit. C 1g/Day. The antioxidant property of Vit. C helps to prevent the conversion to the polymeric material that is deposited in joints.

Related Pearl: Color of urine in different conditions

Normal color of urine is pale straw due to presence of urochrome.

  • Hematological causes, e.g. PNH

  • Beetroot ingestion

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient who presented with generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei called cloverleaf or flower cells. This is characteristic of adult T-Cell leukemia/lymphoma.

This condition occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to one year following diagnosis. It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Skin lesions
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Peripheral blood lymphocytosis,
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray image depicts Chilaiditi sign, characterized by the anterior interposition of the colon between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm, which can mimic air under the diaphragm, leading to pseudo-pneumoperitoneum.

Chilaiditi sign is typically an incidental finding on imaging and is most often asymptomatic. However, when associated with symptoms such as abdominal pain and distension, it is referred to as Chilaiditi syndrome. 

An erect X-ray showing this sign may mislead clinicians into suspecting pneumoperitoneum, prompting unnecessary urgent surgical intervention, which is not required. To differentiate Chilaiditi syndrome from true pneumoperitoneum, a contrast-enhanced CT or a left lateral decubitus radiograph can be performed. In the left lateral decubitus view, distended colonic loops with haustral markings will be visible, showing that the air is within the bowel and not in the peritoneal cavity. 

Other conditions with the Chilaiditi sign are curvilinear pulmonary collapse, distended viscus, omental fat, and apposition of gas-distended bowel loops mimicking the double-wall sign.

Below is the chest X-ray and CT showing the presence of herniated bowel loops under the diaphragm.

Other options:

Option A: The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows free intraperitoneal gas which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. The presence of free intra-abdominal gas almost always indicates perforation of a hollow viscus. Free intraperitoneal gas is also detectable under the hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray as given below. 

Option B: The existence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum is referred to as pneumomediastinum. Gas may originate from the peritoneal cavity, lungs, trachea, central bronchi, oesophagus, or peritoneal cavity and travel to the neck or abdomen via the mediastinum.  Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.  Other signs of pneumomediastinum are the V sign of Naclerio and continuous diaphragm sign. 

Below is a chest X-ray showing spinnaker sign and CT showing the presence of pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: The life cycle given below is of which of the following:
questions.solution:
The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica.

Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir. The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver.

The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcers.

The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces. Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission.

Note: The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman died in the hospital 3 days after she was admitted with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness of her body, along with slurring of speech. An autopsy showed the following finding in the brain. What is this pathological change in this lesion?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a stroke, which results in ischemic injury to the brain. This results in liquefactive necrosis.

Liquefactive necrosis refers to cell death by enzymatic degradation. The brain contains microglial cells, which contain many enzymes. When these cells are broken down, they release these enzymes, resulting in liquefactive necrosis.

The various types of necrosis are as follows:

Type Example
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis

Abscesses

Brain infarct

Wet gangrene
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast
Fibrinoid necrosis

Vasculitis

Aschoff bodies

Malignant hypertension

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a history of diarrhoea, stools sticking to the toilet pane and weight loss over the past 2 years. The patient now presents with skin lesions, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the correct statement about the condition?

choices.text: Laboratory diagnosis is by culture of skin swab
Laboratory diagnosis is by Woods lamp
Laboratory diagnosis is by direct immunofluorescence

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of malabsorption and skin lesions, which is suspicious of celiac disease. The gold standard test for diagnosis is direct immunofluorescence (DIF). DIF classically demonstrates granular deposits of IgA within the papillary dermis.

The skin lesion shown is dermatitis herpetiformis, which is an autoimmune cutaneous eruption associated with gluten sensitivity. These lesions include intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, scalp, or buttocks. Patients with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) also have an associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). In most of the patients with DH, the enteropathy is asymptomatic.

DH usually responds well to treatment. Dapsone and a gluten-free diet are the primary interventions for the management of this disease.

The gold standard test for diagnosis is direct immunofluorescence (DIF). Serologic studies that identify circulating IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase, epidermal transglutaminase, and endomysium are useful for confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: The sonography demonstrates:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasonograph demonstrates overlapping skull bones, also known as Spalding sign. 

Option A: Spalding sign

  • The irregular overlapping of cranial bones on one another is due to liquefaction of brain and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the vault.
  • It usually appears 7 days after death

Option B: Roberts sign

  • Earliest sign of IUD - seen within 12 hours of death
  • The presence of gas shadow within the chambers of the heart and in large vessels of the fetus.

Option C: Blair-Hartley/Ball: sign 

  • Hyperextension/hyperflexion of spine with crowding of ribs
  • Usually seen 3-4 weeks after death
Sign Interval (After Death)
Robert sign (gas in great vessels) 12h
Spalding sign (overlapping of skull bones) 1 week
Blair-Hartley / Ball sign (hyperflexion / hyperextension of spine over ovecrowding of ribs) 3-4 weeks

questions.text: During the routine ophthalmic examination of a 6-year- old child as a part of a school health survey, you notice the following finding as shown in the image. This is characteristically associated with deficiency of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows corneal vascularization, which is characteristic of Riboflavin deficiency. Other features include glossitis, cheilosis, and photophobia collectively called ariboflavinosis. 

The image below shows Cheilosis and glossitis
