questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication?
questions.solution:
The given image shows generation of mRNA from negative sense RNA within the nucleus. This occurs during the replication of influenza virus.

Orthomyxoviruses (influenza virus) contain segmented (8 segments) negative sense ssRNA that is replicated in the nucleus. Stages of viral replication include the following: 

  1. Attachment, penetration, uncoating: The virus attaches to cell-surface sialic acid via hemagglutinin. It is then internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis. There is fusion of the viral envelope and cell membrane, resulting in uncoating or release of nucleocapsid into the host cell cytoplasm. 
  2. Transcription and translation:  mRNAs are produced from nucleocapsids via a virus-encoded polymerase. This process occurs in the nucleus. The mRNAs thus produced are translated into viral proteins in the cytoplasm. 
  3. Viral RNA replication: The viral genome is replicated by the same virus-encoded polymerase involved in transcription. The negative sense RNA is converted to its positive sense form. The positive sense copies serve as templates for replication of the viral genome. 
  4. Maturation: The virus matures by budding from the surface of the cell.

questions.text: The following suture material gets absorbed in how many days?
questions.solution: The image shows a violet color braided multifilament suture material which is vicryl (polyglactin). It gets absorbed completely in 60-90 days.

questions.text: Which of the following antifungal drugs is matched correctly with its mechanism of action based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is an amphipathic molecule and incorporates itself in the cell membrane by actively binding to ergosterol (as shown in the image by 'C'). This results in the formation of amphotericin-induced pores which cause leakage of the intracellular contents ultimately resulting in cell death.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides immitis, Aspergillus.

Amphotericin B also has antiprotozoal action along with antifungal properties and is effective against Leishmania.

Adverse effects of amphotericin B include:

  • Infusion-related fever and chills
  • Azotemia/nephrotoxicity- all lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B
  • Renal tubular acidosis 
  • Renal wasting of potassium and magnesium
  • Hypochromic normocytic anemia- due to decreased erythropoietin production from the kidney.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Name  the instrument given below is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Czerny's retractor. Czerny’s Retractor is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

Option A: Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving a maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Option C: Double hook Retractor is used:

  • To retract skin flap for excision of sebaceous cyst.
  • During venesection for retraction of skin.
  • During tracheostomy for retraction of skin and thyroid isthmus.

Option D: Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

Deaver's Retractor:

Morris retractor:

questions.text: A consultant asked a junior resident to assess the ease of endotracheal intubation in a patient to be operated. The findings were similar to the schematic image given below. The resident should grade the oral opening as Mallampati class ___________
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, the base of the uvula, and the hard palate are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class III.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. In addition to classes I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and the tongue is protruded.

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of a difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presents to the clinic with the following skin lesion. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
This "classic" bull's-eye rash is also called erythema migrans. This lesion is usually seen in individuals with Lyme’s disease.
In children with Lyme disease amoxicillin is the drug of choice.

Doxycycline is generally the drug of choice in Lyme’s disease except in pregnant, lactating women and children under 8 where amoxicillin is used.
Doxycycline is preferred because it has excellent CNS penetration and it can be used to treat anaplasmosis which can coexist with the Lyme’s disease.

Ceftriaxone is reserved for patients with late neurological findings.
Although Azithromycin can be used for treatment treating with amoxicillin gave superior results and shorter treatment time.

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seashore sign seen in M-mode imaging of the normal lung.

M-mode is defined as the time-motion display of the ultrasound wave along a chosen ultrasound line. With M-Mode, even rapid motions can be displayed, measured, and recorded.

In the M-mode of USG, the motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves', and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing in onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in a normal lung.

Option A: Stratosphere sign or barcode sign is a finding in the M-mode seen as parallel horizontal lines above and below the pleural line. This is seen in pneumothorax.

Option C: There is no named sign called troposphere sign.

Option D: Mirror image artifact is seen when there is a highly reflective surface (eg: Diaphragm) in the path of the primary beam.

questions.text: The egg shown in the given image is recovered from the perianal region using the scotch tape technique. Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
The egg shown in the given image is that of Enterobius vermicularis.

The eggs of E. vermicularis are plano-convex in shape, have a double-layered outer shell, and are approximately 50–60 μm in length. Infectious larvae, which are tadpole-shaped, are often visible inside the egg. Unlike those of other intestinal nematodes, these eggs are not found in the stools. The female worm lays eggs in the perianal region.

The eggs are recovered using the scotch tape technique in the morning before a bowel movement. Transparent scotch tape is applied directly to the perianal area and then placed on a microscope slide for examination.

Other options: 

Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are large, broadly oval, with thick mammillated shell, and are typically stained golden brown with bile.

Ancylostoma duodenale eggs are oval and thin-shelled and contain a clearly visible four to eight-cell stage embryo. There is a characteristic clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.

Strongyloides stercoralis eggs hatch within the mucosa of the small intestine forming rhabditiform larvae. These larvae are passed in the stools, not the eggs.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.

It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus.

The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration.

Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below.

Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below.

Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of ________
questions.solution:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans. 

Candida species, when cultured, grow as oval, budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. Unlike other species of candida, Candida albicans can also produce true hyphae or germ tubes. This can be demonstrated after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well. Another distinguishing feature of C. albicans is that it produces large, spherical chlamydospores on nutritionally deficient media.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness. He was ordered a sleep EEG and the following results were recorded. Which stage of sleep does this EEG pattern represent?

REM - Rapid Eye Movement
questions.solution:
The stage of sleep the given EEG pattern represents is the non-REM (non-rapid eye movement) stage 2 sleep. This is characterized by the presence of sleep spindles (sinusoidal waves) and K complexes (high voltage biphasic waves).

An EEG is a recording that represents the electrical activity of the brain and it represents localizing neuropathological lesions.

The following image shows different EEG changes that occur in different stages of sleep - 

Related Pearl: Difference between NREM and REM Sleep

Physiological Process

NREM

REM

Brain activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases in motor and sensory areas, while other areas are similar to NREM

Heart rate

Slows from wakefulness

Increases and varies compared to NREM

Blood pressure

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases (up to 30 percent) and varies from NREM

Sympathetic nerve activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases significantly from wakefulness

Muscle tone

Similar to wakefulness

Absent

Blood flow to brain

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases from NREM, depending on brain region

Respiration

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from NREM, but may show brief stoppages; coughing suppressed

Airway resistance

Increases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from wakefulness

Body temperature

Is regulated at lower set point than wakefulness; shivering initiated at lower temperature than during wakefulness

Is not regulated; no shivering or sweating; temperature drifts toward that of the local environment

Sexual arousal

Occurs infrequently

Greater than NREM

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of 7 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her ultrasound scan is shown below. What does the red arrowhead represent?
questions.solution:
The red arrowhead represents the yolk sac. The yellow arrowhead shows the double ring - outer decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis. 

It is referred to as the double decidua sign and is seen in the first trimester transvaginal sonogram. It is useful to confirm an early intrauterine location for the pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
In the given image, which of the following structures are matched correctly?
  1. A-Ectocyst
  2. C-Scolex
  3. D-Brood capsules
  4. F-Endocyst
  5. H-Hydatid sand
questions.solution:
F -Endocyst and H-Hydatid sand are matched correctly.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of sheep and dogs as hosts. Humans are accidental hosts.

A hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called pericyst that is derived from the host tissue.

The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.

The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. 

The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

questions.text: The instrument in the given image is used to take the sample from:
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take sample from the endocervix for Pap smear.

Ayre’s spatula is used to take sample from squamocolumnar junction.

questions.text: The given egg is of:
questions.solution:
Given egg is elongated with lateral spine. Hence it is an egg of Schistosoma mansoni.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of spine as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: What occurs at 2 in the cardiac muscle action potential shown?
questions.solution:
The plateau phase (shown by 2 in the image) is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.

Phases of cardiac action potential:

  • 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot
    • Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+channels
  • 1→ Initial rapid repolarization
    • Due to closure of Na+channels and opening up of K+channels
  • 2→ Plateau phase
    • Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+channels
  • 3→ Late rapid repolarization
  • 4→ Baseline (RMP)
    • Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux through K+ channels.
  • Until about half of phase 3 of the cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady who had tested positive for HPV  is undergoing an investigation where the following device is used. Which of the following statements is false about this investigation?

choices.text: It is used in lithotomy position
Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position.

This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: The image shows:
questions.solution:
The image in question shows Fuller’s Bivalved Metallic tracheostomy tube.

questions.text: Of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest x-ray except:
questions.solution:
The given chest x-ray shows an egg-on-string appearance seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). Enlargement of the left atrium is seen in TGA, not the right atrium.

The reason for left atrial enlargement is due to increased pulmonary blood flow.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This abnormal configuration leads to a narrow vascular pedicle.

As pulmonary vascular resistance drops during the first few days of life, blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature is increased. There is also elevated pulmonary venous pressure seen in TGA, especially in infants with an intact interventricular septum.

The globular (egg) appearance of the heart due to abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and the narrow superior mediastinum (string) result in the classical egg-on-string appearance.

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers.

Early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductus arteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy is a palliative catheter-based intervention that can be done to improve the hypoxic state before definitive surgery. The procedure creates an opening in the atrial septum which allows better inter-circulatory mixing of the blood. Jatene arterial switch procedure is the definitive surgery. 

Most infants with TGA do not survive till adulthood without corrective surgery.

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A patient who is under general anaesthesia shows the following finding on the ET CO2 monitor. Which condition can lead to this characteristic waveform on capnography?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform depicts bronchospasm. 

Shark fin appearance - Prolonged phase II, increased α angle, and steeper phase III suggest bronchospasm or airway obstruction.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformity known as?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner which is known as crooked nose deformity.

 

Option B: Deviated nose - midline is straight but deviated to one side.

Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum.

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: The lead fragments when stripped from the bullet as it travels through the body, cause multiple fragments along the wound track. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Lead snowstorm is the phenomenon caused by a firearm wound, when lead fragments are stripped from the bullet as it travels through the body. It causing multiple fragments to be present along the wound track.

This phenomenon is caused by semi-jacketed hunting ammunition used in rifled guns.

questions.text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.

choices.text: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation

questions.solution:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division.

Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Post-splenectomy patients
  • Lead poisoning
  • Hemolytic anemias 

Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency.

Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease.

Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

questions.text: The following images are characteristic of _____.
questions.solution:
Melkersson–Rosenthal Syndrome is a triad of

  • Recurrent facial paralysis
  • Recurrent orofacial edema
  • Fissured tongue (lingua plicata)

The major diagnostic criterion is persistent or recurrent non-pitting facial edema that cannot be explained by infection, malignancy, or connective tissue disorder. The edematous lips assume a chapped, fissured, red-brown appearance.

Facial paralysis is the least common symptom of the triad, and it has an abrupt onset that is identical to that in Bell's palsy.

questions.text: The given image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of Heinz bodies and bite cells suggestive of Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

In Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, after oxidant drug exposure, the peripheral blood smear shows red cells with precipitates of denatured globin which are known as Heinz bodies. 

As the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells similar to the one in this smear are produced.

questions.text: What is the type of strangulation shown in this image called?
questions.solution:
The image shows the tightening of a noose around the neck by twisting a rod within the ligature. This is called garrotting. 

This is a mode of ligature strangulation that may be seen in homicide.

This was a form of judicial execution once employed in Spain. The rod-like object used to tighten the ligature is called a Spanish windlass - this may be a ruler, stick, or screwdriver. The method was also used by Thagi’s in the past in India, to kill the travelers and rob their belongings in lonely places.

questions.text: What does I.P in the following indicate?
questions.solution:
The IP in the image indicates Indian Pharmacopoeia

  • Pharmacopoeia contains the description of chemical structure, assay methods, solubility, standards of purity and other information regarding manufacturing of medicines.
  • They are useful to drug manufacturers and regulatory authorities. It indicates that the standards present in the mentioned pharmacopoeia are followed.

Examples of pharmacopoeia:

  • IP: Indian Pharmacopoeia
  • BP: British Pharmacopoeia
  • USP: United States Pharmacopoeia

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given left ventricular pressure-volume curve:
questions.solution:
The ejection fraction as calculated from the above volume pressure curve is 60%.

The ejection fraction is defined as the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke.

Thus, EF = Volume ejected / End diastolic volume × 100

The volume ejected can be obtained, by subtracting the end systolic volume from end diastolic volume. Thus,

EF = End diastolic volume (EDV) − End systolic volume (ESV) / End diastolic volume (EDV) × 100

In the above volume pressure curve of left ventricle,

EDV = 130 ml

ESV = 52 ml

Substituting these values in the above equation we get,

EF = (130 − 52 / 130) × 100

 = (3 / 5) × 100

 = 0.6 × 100

 = 60%

Related information:

The ejection fraction is a valuable index of the ventricular function. It is measured by injecting radionuclide-labeled red blood cells and imaging the volume of the blood at the end of diastole and the end of systole (equilibrium radionuclide angiocardiography), or by computed tomography.

The normal left ventricular ejection fraction is 50% to 70%.

In heart failure, ejection fraction may be preserved or reduced,

  • Preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) – also referred to as diastolic heart failure. The heart muscle contracts normally but the ventricles do not relax as they should during ventricular filling (or when the ventricles relax).
  • Reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) – also referred to as systolic heart failure. The heart muscle does not contract effectively and less oxygen-rich blood is pumped out to the body.

LVEF Assessment:

The American college of cardiology (ACC), gives the cardiac function and their corresponding ejection fractions

  • Hyperdynamic = LVEF greater than 70%
  • Normal = LVEF 50% to 70% (midpoint 60%)
  • Mild dysfunction = LVEF 40% to 49% (midpoint 45%)
  • Moderate dysfunction = LVEF 30% to 39% (midpoint 35%)
  • Severe dysfunction = LVEF less than 30%

questions.text: What level of structural organization of a protein is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures viz:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein.

questions.text: In a Chi-square test for the following data, the degrees of freedom will be:
questions.solution:
In this scenario,contingency table has 3 rows and 4 columns. Hence, the degree of freedom, df = (3 – 1) (4 – 1) = 6.

In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Auer Rods which are characteristically seen in AML.

  • Auer rods are clumps of azurophilic granular material that appear as elongated needles, seen in the cytoplasm of leukemic blasts.
  • They can be seen in the leukemic blasts of acute myeloid leukemia with maturation and acute promyelocytic leukemia (known as acute myeloid leukemia M2 and M3, in the FAB classification, respectively) and in high-grade myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative syndromes.
  • Morphologically, the Auer "rods" come in all sizes and shapes. They have been described as needle-shaped with pointed ends (most common), comma-shaped, and diamond-shaped; others were long and rectangular.
  • They are also used to distinguish the pre-leukemia myelodysplastic syndromes: refractory anemia with excess blasts 2 (RAEB2) (which has Auer rods) from RAEB 1 (which does not).

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about larva of mosquitoes?

choices.text: Culex larva lies in water with head faced downwards
Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water

questions.solution:
Anopheles larva has no siphon tube as shown in the image below.

The image given below shows Culex larva having a siphon tube.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked A.
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is primary oocyte. Primary oocytes are the germ cells seen in the medullary region of the ovary. These enlarge at the beginning of the growth phase.

During this cell growth period, many oocytes undergo degeneration, both before and after birth. A single layer of flattened follicular cells that were derived originally from the germinal epithelium soon surrounds the primary oocytes. The structure that is formed is now called a primordial follicle. These are seen first in the medulla and later in the cortex.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who was a welder for the past 10 years presents with a dry cough, easy fatiguability, weight loss, and dyspnea progressing over the past 1 year. On examination, fine end-inspiratory crackles were heard over the bilateral infra-axillary regions. His HRCT finding is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The HRCT provided shows a characteristic crazy-paving pattern which is classical of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. 

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a lung disease involving the accumulation of surfactant within the alveoli as a result of decreased clearance. It may be congenital, secondary, or autoimmune.

Etiology:

  • Congenital
  • Secondary: due to lung infections, hematologic malignancies, and inhalation of mineral dust such as silica, titanium oxide, aluminum, indium-tin-oxide, and insecticides.
  • Autoimmune: autoantibodies against GM-CSF

Patients may have features like a persistent dry cough (or with scant sputum production), progressive dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, intermittent low-grade fever and/or night sweats, and pleuritic chest pain. Rarely, they may have cyanosis and hemoptysis. The physical examination will show fine end-inspiratory crackles. Clubbing and cyanosis may be present in a few cases.

Diagnosis is with bronchoscopic lavage and/or biopsy, along with imaging findings. Chest X-ray shows nonspecific findings with bilateral lung opacification. A batwing appearance may be seen.

The CT shows a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern. It refers to geographical areas of ground-glass opacification with thickened inter-and intralobular septa.

Treatment includes whole lung lavage and treatment of the underlying cause. GM-CSF replacement is considered if an underlying autoimmune etiology is suspected.

Other causes causing similar crazy-paving appearance:

  • Lipoid pneumonia
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia
  • Silicosis,
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta -  In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
    • Preterm delivery
    • Abortions
    • IUGR
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Retained placenta and membranes

Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.

Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: An elderly patient with chronic black tarry stools underwent an upper GI endoscopy. Gastric mucosa appeared as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the snake-skin appearance of the gastric mucosa, which is seen in cases of portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Portal hypertensive gastropathy is characterized by the diffuse dila­tion of the mucosal and submucosal venous plexus of the stomach associated with overlying gastritis.

Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly, characterized endoscopically by watermelon stripes. It is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, cardiac, and renal diseases.

Option C: Hypoproteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare, acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or no acid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor-alpha.

Option D: Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a large tortuous arteriole that erodes and bleeds and occurs most commonly in the stomach wall.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. His moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for him?
questions.solution:
The patient has rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid-cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year

Episodes either have a partial or full remission for at least 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine has been found to have limited uses in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. It can prolong the time between depression and mania.

Option C: Carbamazepine takes 2-3 weeks for the onset of action and is used in patients not responding to Lithium in Acute Mania.

Option D: Lithium takes 5-7 days to achieve a level of equilibrium, moreover it is effective in Bipolar I disorder and is less efficacious than Divalproex in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder.

 

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add-on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:

  1. Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
  2. Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant. 
  3. Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  4. Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: The stain used for melanin in the below image is
questions.solution:
The stain used for melanin in the above image is Masson Fontana stain. Other stains for melanin are Schmorl’s method and an enzyme histochemical method called DOPA oxidase method. This DOPA oxidase method is the most specific stain for melanin.

Other options:

  • Oil red stains neutral lipids and fatty acids
  • PAS stains glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoproteins and fungi
  • Gomori methamine stains fungi

questions.text: Which of the following diseases primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Other options:

Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe.

Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

questions.text: The following image shows the embryological development of the heart. What is the origin of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the valve of foramen ovale. This is formed by the septum primum.

In the development of the heart, the interatrial septum is formed by two septums called septum primum and septum secundum. Of this, septum secundum forms the foramen ovale and septum primum forms the valve of the foramen ovale. This valve aids in the unidirectional flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium during the fetal period.

At birth, when the pressure in the left ventricle is increased, the valve of the foramen ovale is opposed against the septum secundum, thereby obliterating the foramen ovale. When this process is defective, this can result in the formation of a patent foramen ovale.

questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells).

questions.text: Which of the following structures drain into the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the deep inguinal lymph node (also known as the node of Cloquet). The glans penis drains into the deep inguinal lymph nodes whereas, the rest of the penis drains into the superficial lymph nodes.

The scrotum drains into superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following zones gives rise to benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
The zone marked C  is the transitional zone and it gives rise to benign prostatic hyperplasia. It is identified by its location, as it encircles the urethra. Therefore, it is also called the periurethral zone.

Zones of prostate and their clinical importance:

questions.text: You see a resident use the following instrument to grasp the anterior lip of the cervix in a patient posted for a vaginal hysterectomy. What is this instrument known as?
questions.solution:
The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed.

Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip.

Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They help in achieving hemostasis by firm pressure.

Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.

questions.text: A young man presents to the OPD with complaints of chronic diarrhea, right lower abdominal pain, and weight loss. On examination, you note a low-grade fever and a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant. Colonoscopy revealed sparing of the rectum. The following endoscopic findings may also be seen in his condition except:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as ileocolitis. Fine granular mucosa is seen in ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease.

Ileocolitis presents as right lower abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea. Pain is usually colicky and is relieved by defecation. It may mimic acute appendicitis in the early stages.

Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas.

questions.text: A patient died due to poisoning with a substance that inhibits the complex of the electron transport chain that is marked in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be the substance?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the complex of the electron transport chain shown is complex IV and carbon monoxide inhibits complex IV.

Molecules like glucose undergo a series of oxidation reactions to produce CO2 and water. The metabolic intermediates of these reactions donate electrons to NAD and FAD to form NADH and FADH2. They, in turn, donate a pair of electrons to a specialized set of electron carriers called the electron transport chain. 

The electron chain is present in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It has are 4 protein complexes, named complex-I, II, III, and IV. These complexes are connected by two carriers- co-enzyme Q and cytochrome C. The complexes and their inhibitors are summarized below.

Complexes of ETC   Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase Carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL(British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV:  cytochrome c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

 

The following image shows different compounds inhibiting the different components in an electron transport chain.

questions.text: Which of the following sets of measures of central tendency is likely to match the distribution depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a right-skewed or positively skewed distribution. So, among the given options, the most likely values of mean = 3, median = 2, and mode = 1.

We can tell the direction of skew of a distribution by observing the direction of the tail. Here, the tail of the distribution is towards the positive direction and thus it is positively skewed or right-skewed. In a positively skewed distribution, mean > median > mode. 

If the tail of the distribution is towards the negative direction, the distribution would be negatively skewed or left-skewed. In such distributions, mode > median > mean.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for his myopia. He is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on him.
questions.solution:
The above image is of the dynamic contour tonometer such as the Pascal tonometer. The dynamic contour tonometer(Pascal) offers a non-invasive and direct method of intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement with an additional measurement of the ocular pulse amplitude. This type of tonometer is unaffected by the corneal thickness and it is the tonometer of choice in post-Lasik patients.

Option A: Pachymetry is used to measure the corneal thickness. 
The below image is of pachymetry.

 

Option C: Auto Refractotemetry is a computerized refractometer that is used to find out the error of refraction. This gives rapid information about the kind of refractive error in terms of sphere, cylinder with axis and inter pupillary distance.

Option D: A-Scan ultrasonography is a useful diagnostic tool for intraocular evaluation especially in the setting of opaque media. The report of the A scan is displayed as a unidimensional display of spikes along a baseline where the distance between the spikes gives the indirect measurement of the tissues. A-scan is used to measure

  • The axial length of the eyeball for Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation
  • Anterior chamber depth
  • Thickness of intraocular mass.    

A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below.

questions.text: What test is being performed in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the given image is diascopy.

It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows other colors to be evaluated.

Some uses of diascopy are as follows: 

  • Apple jelly nodules -  Yellow-brown lesions seen in lupus vulgaris and sarcoidosis.
  • Spider naevi - Compression of radiating arterioles is noted. 
  • Differentiation of erythema (disappears) and purpura (remains unaltered).

The image given below shows apple-jelly nodules on diascopy.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a cancellous screw.

Cancellous screws have a larger thread and high pitch. Compression is produced by partial threading with a blunt tip.

A malleolar screw is a modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip.

Cortical screws have a smaller thread and low pitch. Compression is produced by over-drilling the proximal cortex.

questions.text: What does the following image show?
questions.solution:
The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage.

The cells frequently involved are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Both the cells are viable and there are no physiological and morphological consequences to either of them.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The above image is of a joule burn which is specific and diagnostic of electric burns and is found at the point of entry.  

Joule burn is a specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity and is found at the point of entry of the current. It is seen in accidents with high-tension currents. It is an endogenous thermal burn due to the heat generated in the body from electricity. These marks are round or oval, shallow craters, 1-2 cm in diameter, and raised borders around part or the whole of their circumference.
The crater floor is lined by pale flattened skin. The presence of an areola of blanched skin is seen at the periphery of the joule burn, which survives death and is pathognomonic of electrical damage.

Other important features of electrical injuries:

  • Flash / Spark burns - results when there is a high voltage electrical injury and contact between metal and skin is loose. It is an exogenous burn, keratin melts in the skin producing brownish keratin nodules with pale areola. Very high voltage currents produce massive destruction of tissue with loss of extremities and rupture of organs. 
  • Crocodile burns - multiple nodules on the skin due to high voltage electrical injury over a large body surface. 
  • Bone pearls or wax drippings - heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate which is seen in X-rays of limbs as typical round dense foci. 

Other options:

Option A: Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling, and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Option B: Frost Bite:

Below is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures (-2.5° C), is only produced during life, and cannot be caused postmortem.

Option D: Scalding: Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam (image shown below).

questions.text: The posture shown in image is seen in :
questions.solution:
The given image shows decorticate posturing. It is caused due to upper midbrain damage.

Decorticate posture is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain. The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended. Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture is caused by damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons. Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants exhibit the following response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine exhibits the above-given response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol:

  • This is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.
  • It is most commonly done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle of the hand.
  • Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength is given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

When an agent belonging to the curare group which are the nondepolarizing/competitive blockers is used, it shows fade phenomenon. This is because, during the initial stimulus, the amount of acetylcholine released is large enough to compete with the drug at the motor endplate and causes the maximal contraction of the muscle. But, during the successive stimuli, the amount of acetylcholine released is not sufficient to compete with the drug and results in diminished contractions sequentially. This is called as the Fade phenomenon.

When succinylcholine, the only depolarising agent in clinical use is used the train of four protocol does not show fade phenomenon. This happens so because there is no competition that exists between Sch and Ach. Also, succinylcholine acts like acetylcholine at its receptors but they are not easily metabolized by acetylcholinesterases resulting in persistent depolarisation. This is phase 1 blockade.

But when the dose of succinylcholine is increased maximally, it also exhibits a fade phenomenon. This is phase 2 blockade.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the marked zone?

choices.text: This zone is an example of dysplasia
This zone does not take up the iodine in VILI test
The formation of this zone is influenced by progesterone
Nabothian cysts are seen in this zone

questions.solution:
The marked zone is the transformation zone. When the overgrowing new squamous epithelium as a result of metaplasia blocks the cervical crypts in the transformation zone, they turn into a mucus-filled small structure called the nabothian cyst.

Salient features of the transformation zone:

  • The area between the old and new squamocolumnar junction is called the transformation zone.
  • This stands as an example of metaplasia wherein, the columnar epithelium of the exposed endocervical canal is transformed into another type of mature epithelium (squamous epithelium).
  • Various hyperestrogenic states such as puberty, pregnancy, and OCP result in the exposure of the endocervical columnar epithelium beyond external os, thus augmenting the formation of the transition zone.
  • This zone acts as the central point in giving rise to various premalignant lesions due to the continuous cellular turnover that happens in this zone.
  • As this zone contains squamous epithelium with glycogen in it, they take up iodine when stained with Lugol’s iodine in VILI test.

questions.text:
Which among the following incisions is made during LSCS?

LSCS- Lower segment Cesarean section
questions.solution:
Pfannenstiel incision, represented by 4 in the image above is the most common incision made in lower section caesarean delivery.

It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curbvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

The various incisions mentioned in the image are:

Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision.

Incision '2' - The Maylard incision is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.

Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney. 

It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.

Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
The compound has three ionisable side chains
The compound has one ionisable group

questions.solution:
The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pK1 and pK2 of the compound.

Other options:

  • The points A and B represent the pKa of carboxyl and amino groups respectively.
  • The amino acid has no ionizable side chains as the graph shows only two pKas.
  • The amino acid has two ionizable groups: an amino group and a carboxyl group.

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

Titration curve of Glycine:

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO-.

pK1 and pK2 correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the aminoacid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • The presence of two pKas indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • The presence of three or more pKas indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.
